And I am sure that many members opposite are now finding that those are not very pleasant and, in many cases, are absolutely and totally impractical. I suggest they read the report from the parliamentary inquiry into user charges to find out what we proposed and see whether it is being done. I can assure them it is not. This is about saving half a billion dollars. If it does not work-and I am sure it will not because it will not provide the half a billion dollars unless fees are well over $lOO,OOO-then the nursing home stock will actually run down further. The problem we faced when in government was a substantial expansion in the numbers requiring nursing homes. Our massive investment in hostel care, which, quite frankly, was barely available in 1983, our substantial involvement in funding the HACC system, which was not there in 1983, plus our expansion of nursing homes were still not enough to meet the demand. The Gregory report was correct, because the other part of all that was the shift in levels of expectation and, as I mentioned earlier, the de-institutionalisation program. People were being transferred from hospitals and institutions to nursing homes. They were shifted from the state responsibility to the Commonwealth responsibility. That does not show up in the figures because that was never measured, but we all know it took place. So what we have here is a recipe for disaster. And why? Because it is not policy driven. It is driven by the budget. It is driven by finding half a billion dollars in savings in what appears to be a large, fat, lucrative area where money can be cut. That is what it is about. What we have heard since then has been an attempt to justify why that cut would occur in this area and not somewhere else. The aged of Australia and their families are saying, 'Why us?' The idea that somehow it is equivalent to hostel entry fees is absolutely deceptive, misleading and very nasty. People who enter hostels have some choice about their lives. The equivalent of this nursing home up-front fee is not hostels but hospitals. People do not choose to go into hospital. They are admitted on medical grounds, because they are required to. People go into nursing homes because they are required to; there is no choice. This is not a question of choosing one or the other. There is no choice. You are giving them the choice of a nursing home or death. That is the choice you are giving them, and it is becoming very stark. The more you talk about this being an improvement, the more you will reinforce the devaluation of our aged community and the more they will see themselves as a source of money. They will not give it to you. They will die first. That is what they are thinking and that is what they are saying. We did not create this problem. There is the idea that somehow we created this problem. The fact is that in the last budget you announced a half billion dollar cut to residential aged care support. Once you announced that, you caused a problem. The more you deny it and pretend it is about improving the aged care and residential care systems, the bigger the hole you dig and the more y:m devalue our aged community. This is a nasty bit of legislation. It is discriminatory and it is vicious. But it is not about social policy or aged care policy; it is about budget policy. It is about a government that is more concerned with dollars than with people. It will lead to a running down of the aged care system, it will lead to granny squatting and it will lead to a massive lack of confidence in our aged care system. We had a system that was one of the world's best. We are heading for a system that will be one of the world's worse. As those opposite smile, laugh and carry on, the aged of Australia are watching them. They understand. Make no mistake: being old does not make you stupid. These people are not stupid. They know the situation Members opposite should talk to the pensioner organisations and the caring community. They understand this stuff very well. They are very aware of what you are doing. Do not patronise them and do not take them for granted, because they know that this is not about helping them; this is about cutting money out of the budgeL The more you say it is about an aged care policy, the more they realise how hypocritical you are.

Speaker: Mr MCDOUGALL
Title: PAIRS
text: In addressing the Aged Care Bill, I remind the House that health services and aged care are two of the fastest growing federal costs since the mid-1970s. I do not believe there is a person on either side of this House who does not acknowledge the need for major reform to protect the future of the ageing members of our community. The tragedy is that the system this government inherited had not seen effective change for over a decade. The results are clear to see. Nursing homes are in crisis. When this government took a look at the nursing homes throughout the nation, it met with an unpleasant shock. Eleven per cent of our nursing homes do not meet fire standards, 15 per cent of nursing homes do not meet state health standards and 40 per cent of nursing home patients are in four-bed or more wards. Recently a Health and Family Services senior officer advised me that, under the previous government, the department did not check the physical standards of aged care . facilities. This was never part of the standards set and is a most serious failing of the exist. mg system. There is an imbalance in not just the funding for aged care facilities but also the type of facilities available. The Aged Care Bill is the first step along the path of improving the security and lifestyle of our aged. The Aged Care Bill is a package. It is not a quick fix solution. It creates an environment to generate funds into the nursing home sector. At the same time, it ensures that access to quality care is based on care needs, not on the means to pay. This major reform to aged care abolishes the two-tiered aged care system and replaces it with a focus on the type of care very well -"needed by residents. To ensure all hostel and nursing home residents receive appropriate care, this bill introduced a new funding structure which applies to all residential. aged care facilities. The eight different care categories range from low care to high care levels and, in particular, dementia care. This ensures all residents of hostels and nursing homes will have their care needs assessed and met. At the same time, this bill eliminates the significant overlap of care between hostels and nursing homes. This bill also addresses the all but ignored residents who have dementia. This reform means residents needing dementia care will benefit from an increase in funds by over 30 per cent. This government recognised what the previous government ignored: the need for a minimum capital injection of $125 million a year to the nursing home sector. The previous government's aged care proposal was for $12.9 million-a shortfall of well over $100 million. No-one pretends major reform is going to be fast. But this new strategy is a powerful start. The Aged Care Bill is a reform package which will not only allow the nursing home sector to rebuild and offer quality aged care but also eliminate the confusing difference in fees charged by hostels and nursing homes. Under the new system, all residents will pay a standard daily fee based on 85 per cent of the age pension. The income tested fee will apply only to income above the pension-free area, which still stands at $49 a week above the full pension. Due to the inequity of the hostel versus nursing home system, we have seen a gradual decline in the standards of nursing homes. Hostels charge entry contributions. As a result, they have had that extra capital and have been of reasonably good standard. Nursing homes, on the other hand, lived on a hand-to-mouth existence, and it shows. To address the situation the government has allocated a substantial capital funding program to assist those facilities which need help. Forty million dollars is available over the next four years. It is expected that these funds will be used by nursing homes with a high proportion of concessional residents. A major key to this bill is the funding to be injected into the nursing home sector by accommodation bonds. That entry contributions have been a way of life for hostel residents has been accepted by the community. Therefore, I am amazed that the opposition, led by the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin)-fast becoming known as the shadow minister for scare-has spent weeks terrorising our mature age citizens with empty threats that this will mean that they will lose their homes. They will not, and neither will it spouse, close family member or long-term carer be expected to leave the family home if one member goes into an aged care facility. This has been declared publicly by the Minister for - amily Services ad infinitum. There are many other provisions in this bill to protect those who pay accommodation bonds, provisions which are rarely touted in the press by the opposition. For instance, people who can afford to pay a bond will not have to pay a lump sum up-front but have several options, including periodic payments. Those who have no assets or income will have a place in an aged care facility. This reform locks nursing homes into setting aside a national average of 27 per cent of peds for concessional residents. Those who cannot care for themselves will be cared for by this government. This leads me to another one of the opposi tion' s favoured scare tactics-that nursing homes are to receive only $5 a day for concessional residents. What the opposition fails to mention is that this is an additional $66 million injection into the nursing home section. The former government had planned to do the same thing but were only coming up with $3. It is also in addition to the existing daily amount received by all aged care facilities for concessional residents. This reform will for the first time in a decade adequately address the capital funding crisis in nursing homes. I do not believe it is unreasonable for those who have assets to be income tellted when they choose to go into an aged care facility. Nor do I believe that the community disagrees with the principle that it is much fairer for people to draw on their savings to pay for their own care rather than expect the taxpayers to do so. The people of Australia are already burdened with the debt of $10 billion that Labor left this government with. This government has no intention of plundering those taxpayers' incomes any further. People are used to selling one home to move on to the next. So why not do so when they choose to move into a nursing home and adopt the special care that goes with that lifestyle? We all have to acknowledge that, while the over 65-year-olds comprise only 12 per cent of the population, they absorb 33.5 per cent of the health budget-and that was in 1990. In the next generation, this will reach 50 per cent. This is not unique or unexpected. Only the previous Keating government sought to ignore the needs of the slowly crumbling nursing home system, which has now reached this crisis point. The previous government had the same figures to hand but ignored the fact that our baby boomers are only a decade from retirement. Demographers can tell us with deadly accuracy that, by the year 2030, 20 per cent of the population will be over 65. The young will have to work doubly hard to support them. To coin the old cliche, two things are certain in life: death and taxes. I will adjust that to say that two things are certain in life: ageing and taxes. I recall vividly a documentary I saw many years ago on the life of eskimos. In that harsh environment, when the older members of the family could no longer contribute to its survival, they walked out onto the ice, sat down and died. Fortunately, our environment is not quite so taxing and we still enjoy life to the fullest in our senior years. The senior members of our community are also able to continue to contribute to their families and to the community due to the advances we have in health and care. This government recognises the true value of extended families, of grandparents and greatgrandparents and the urgent need to address the ongoing matter of their care. This reform also paves the way for simplicity for providers. In setting the path for a single national rate of subsidy, we will dramatically reduce the red tape and paperwork for the operators of our aged care facilities. In essence, hostels have worked on a single national rate of subsidy and have always had the responsibility for their staffing mix and how they spend their government subsidy. We are doing the same thing in the nursing home sector. They will still be accountable and must adhere to strict standards, but these will certainly be a vast improvement on what we inherited when we took government. In too many cases, residents have had to endure unacceptable living conditions. The opposition will argue that they did put checks and balances into place, but the facts are plain to see. The aged care system we inherited focused on minimum standards of quality control. This will not be the case in the future. Providers who do not meet high standards will be out of the industry. The blame does not lie with the nursing home providers but with the system which did not offer any recognition for providing quality care. Dementia care, for example, was most certainly not properly addressed. This aged care reform addresses the all important issue of special care for those with that special need. Funding for dementia care will increase by over 30 per cent on average, providing much needed support for both dementia specific units and mainstream facilities. But possibly one of the greatest areas of change has been our reforms in recognising the different and varied needs for people turning to aged care facilities. In creating new classification scales for the different levels of aged care requirements, hostels and nursing homes will be funded accordingly. The system we are introducing is simpler and far less complicated than the old system. Professor Bob Gregory's 1994 report to the former government recommended that $125 million a year needed to be spent to bring nursing home infrastructure costs up to an acceptable level. The former government's response was to allocate $10 million a year. These funds had to be spent on staffing, infrastructure costs and all other ongoing expenditure. The aged care system we inherited focused on minimum standards and was a mess of bureaucracy and red tape. Not only was there a minimum standard of quality controlwhich some providers have been straddling with only centimetres to spare-but there was no recognition, as I said, of good quality care. Therefore, there has been no incentive to be the best care provider. That the previous government gave little or no thought to aged care reform is evident in their so-called aged care reform strategy of their last 10 years in government. This revealing document does not even fill one page. In fact, Labor's aged care reform strategy covers just eight short paragraphs with 207 words. They are delivering more words in objectinto this government's major reforms-reforms which ensure aged care facilities will be accountable to both the government and the families for the levels and quality of care and accommodation they provide. This reform will create the environment for the right care for the right reason, and it cannot be written off in less than a page, as Labor managed to do. I support the bill.  with the honourable member for Griffith (Mr MCDougall) when he said in speaking to these aged care bills that there are two things that are certain in life-death and taxes. And what we are dealing with today is a tax. In fact, you might say it is a premature death tax. The member for Griffith made great play of Labor's policy at the last election. Madam Deputy Speaker, please offer me indulgence and allow me to read into the Hansard record exactly what the coalition's policy was at the election and see if we can recognise the difference between their policy at that time and this bill. I think you may find one or two differences. Their policy stated: The Coalition's aged care policy will: . enable people to choose to stay in their own homes for as long as possible ... What a laugh. It continued: provide a range of residential and community based aged care services which offers real choice to older Australians and their familiesproviding they sell their home. And: provide genuine support for residential facilities caring for people suffering from various levels of dementia . . . I acknowledge that the government has done something about that. It finished: ensure residential care services meet the standards that are acceptable to the community; adopt a more flexible approach to the provision of residential care, including alternatives to residential care, in rural and remote areas; and recognise the worth of all sectors of the aged care industry charitable commercial sector proprietors and organisations have expertise, and a common interest, in providing the highest possible quality of care for frail older Australians. Where in that policy does it say that frail older Australians-not because they desire nursing home accommodation but because they require it-have to pay an up-front fee for it? Where is the consistency in what the coalition and the government backbenchers said before the election and what they are jumping up now in a sickening way to support? Madam Deputy Speaker, you might not have seen it, but the ACA has issued a press release asking all members of the Houseopposition members and government members-not to let this legislation through. The ACA is the peak body. Do you know what the press release says? It says that, notwithstanding dialogue with the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan), dialogue with her advisers and dialogue with the department, the ACA is still unclear about the implications of this bill and there is still too much detail that is up in the air. The ACA asks all government members and all opposition members not to pass the bill. I cannot say that I am an expert on the legislation. I think it is probably the worse bit of legislation, the worse budget measure, that the coalition proposes to enact. I have to say that I do have reservations about the legislation, but I am influenced by that press release and I will be opposing this bill. I want to pay tribute to the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo MCLeay)-not something that I often do in this House. I notice the shadow minister taking note of thisMr Stephen Smith-And the minister.  (Mr Fahey), who is at the table. It is true that when John Howard was the Treasurer the honourable member for Watson chaired a parliamentary committee and delivered a report into this House. I think it has been one of the most important reports that has been tabled by a parliamentary committee. It is certainly something that the honourable member for Watson and other members who served with him on that committee can take a great deal of comfort in. The title of the report was In home or at home? When we won office in 1983, it was this report that laid the Labor Party's foundations for the HACC program. That was the genesis of the HACC program. The idea was that we ought to allow our frail aged in the community to stay in their own homes for the longest possible time. Not only is that common sense for them and a desirable outcome for them but also it makes good economic sense. In our 13 years in office, we had a very structured approach to aged care. We had the HACC program, allowing more of our older Australians to enjoy their own homes, to enjoy their neighbourhoods and have the familiarity of their own surroundings. We had hostel accommodation for the aged. You do not have to have a medical conditions to get into a hostel; it is an issue of choice. When an aged person's frailty was such that they could no longer be supported either in their own home or in a hostel, we had nursing homes. Madam Deputy Speaker, I am sure that you fully appreciate the fact that it did not how much money you had, if you were assessed by ACAT-the aged care assistance team-which comprises medical experts, nurses and social workers, as requiring ing home care, you were given a place. It not matter if you had two bob in the bank more. I notice that the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus) has said that we supported millionaires in nursing home accommodation. That may be true. If the legislation needs to be tightened up so that millionaires do not take advantage of that, let's tighten it up. But let's not punish all aged Australians because of some millionairbenefit es. We introduced an assets test when we in government. The present government bitterly criticised us. One of the things we did was to take millionaires off the sion. But we did say, 'Your home is sacrothat sanct.' We excluded the home from the assets test. But what is this government doing? dealing the family home in. The government says that, if your spouse is at home or if you have got a carer living with you, you do not have to sell the house. That is true, that is in the legislation, but tell how you find a nursing home place if you not sell the house. What do you expect private providers to do if they have the opportunity of getting even more than the $26,000 that you say this premature death will be? I think everyone now concedes that it is going to be in the order of $80,000 $90,000; they undershot the figure by 300 per cent. If a proprietor can get hold that sort of money and keep the interest draw down $2,500 a year as opposed to taking someone who does not own a home someone who wants to keep the family home, are they going to take the $90,000 or nothing? Left to the marketplace--competition, operatWe ing for profit-what do you reckon is going to happen? We all know. Notwithstanding this legislation, frail aged Australians who have struggled a lifetime get a home will be forced to sell their home to get a nursing home place. That is what this legislation means. That is what you are asking matter us to vote for, and we will not. But the government members are going to get up and say how terrific this legislation is, notwithstanding what was said in 1996 by John nursHoward and what the Minister for Family did Services is introducing into this place now. or What a lot of hypocrisy. What a lot of flipflopping. What a lot of inconsistency. How cruel this is to our frail aged Australians. As ACA, the peak organisation, says, there is still a lot of uncertainty. What are the prudential requirements? I know that the Moran corporation is friendly with the Liberal Party, that it employed former Senator Woods frail as a special adviser and that you are the of this inside information about how private operators operate and what they need were and how this can be made more profitable-I understand that-but when one of our elderly that Australians has actually sold their home and penpaid this up-front fee how do we guarantee it will be protected, that it will always be there, even if there has been a degree of fraud It is or malfeasance? What is the method of protection? What is the method of ensuring that it is properly in trust and always there? The honourable minister at the table is a former solicitor. Solicitors have trust funds me and they are regularly inspected. Notwithdo standing that regular inspection, read the Daily Telegraph, read your local paper, and time after time you will find situations where solicitors have improperly used those funds tax and the solicitor's fidelity fund has got to make up the difference. What is going to to happen to the proceeds of an elderly about Australian's home-that $90,000-when a of proprietor skips off maybe not with the and proceeds of just one home but with the proceeds of quite a number? That is a huge or sum of money. You don't have to have too many residents before you get close to a million dollars. What is going to happen then? do not get the answers in this bill. What the people of Australia really want and what elderly Australians want is to make sure that members of parliament are genuinely to concerned about their needs. They do not really like us bickering, but I must say that it is the individual elements of this bill that make me so passionate about it. What are we going to do to help them? Ho.w can we improve the situation? I am not gomg to stand up in this parliament and say, 'Labor had a perfect system. Nothing could be don- to make it better.' Of course there were thmgs that could make it better and they are the elements that we should be discussing. Yes, we do need better nursing homes. Yes, there should be some incentives for proprietors to improve their homes. But I would be gr.ateful if the Minister for Finance would outlme to the House the competitive elements in this bill that actually force proprietors, particularly these private providers, to improve the nursing homes. If you look at the policy speech that John Howard took to the last election, he did not say that he was going to regulate standards. In fact, he promised self-regulation. You c-n drive a horse and buggy through it. There IS nothing in this bill that ensu-es, mandates - r requires nursing home propnetors to put. thiS money-this premature death tax-mto improving the homes. As knowle-g-able as the minister at the table, the Minister for Finance, and his department are, they will tell you that private providers can drive a horse and buggy through this legislation be-ause they will be able to utilise this money Without improving the nursing homes. From time to time governments do need to make significant changes to policy. I - m not sure that this is one of those occasIOns. I think when you make an intergenerational change like this-that is, you are getting just one sector of the community to leap into a new system-you should have a signific.ant transitional period. If this is what you thmk is so necessary, understand that they need to save and marshall their resources so that they can afford it. The point about this legislation is that there is not going to be one extra nursing home bed as a result of it. Not one. The Labor Party, when in government, justified HECS on the basis that we would take the money and provide extra university places. It was very unpopular at the time and it probably caused more angst on our side of politics than an-Â­ where else. We said, 'It is a new charge. It IS not full cost recovery, only partial cost recovery. But what we are doing with every dollar we collect is to expand the system.' And we did-massively so. However, that is not happening here. What you are doing is clawing back about half .a billion dollars worth of government expenditure. You are putting less into the system than we did. Not only are you asking our aged Australians that they pay-and pay with their homes-for this up-front so-called accommodation bond, variously estimated at $90,000, but you are not guaranteeing in the legislation that nursing homes will im-rove. You are not guaranteeing that there will be extra beds. I know people on the opposition - ide - re going to be constantly frustrated by listemng to government members, as I was when. I listened to the honourable member for Gnffith-I wish I could have been spared that but it is part of my responsibility-becaus- - hey are going to say ad nauseam, as the minister does, 'We may have promised to do a lot of other things and we're sorry we didn't tell you about what we really wanted to do wh-n we went to the last election, but really all thiS is about is hostel accommodation. Labor had this system where you would pay a fee to the hostel for a place. All we are doing is j.ust translating that from hostels to nursmg homes.' Let me repeat the major point: hostel accommodation is about choice. People could stay at home through the HACC progra-, which I mentioned earlier. My own mother IS in that situation. She is contemplating whether she will continue on at home or whether she will go to a nursing home. It has nothing to do with any medical condition or her state of health; it is an element of choice. But people do not choose to go into nursing homes. They have to be properly assessed. There is a compulsion about nursing homes. It is about time government members, when th-y are talking about these vulnerable Austrahans--:our frail aged community who have contnbuted so much to this country to make it what it is today: a place we, the younger generations, can enjoy-said with a bit of honesty what it is that they are doing. The government, unfortunately, was totally dishonest at the last election. John Howard was totally dishonest in his aged care policy. I have already read it to you, Madam Deputy Speaker, and I am sure you are more familiar with it than I am. There is not a hint in that of these draconian measures or this particular draconian bill. I think our older Australians deserve better than that. From time to time the government members have rather viciously attacked our shadow spokesperson, the honourable member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin). She has had a tough job having to speak up, as she has consistently, on behalf of our older Australians. I would encourage her to continue to do so. You are putting this draconian legislation through, and probably going to ram it through the Senate at the well, but it is going to put the Labor Party in an awful position when we come back into office. Surely there are some compassionate members on the government side who will read the press release of the ACA and who will have second thoughts about the impact of this measure on older Australians. Maybe they will not do it in the debate-I would admire them if they did-but perhaps they will take to the party room their real concerns. My electorate is characterised as a young electorate. Compared to other electorates, like that of the honourable member for Hindmarsh, for example, mine has a very small elderly population. But, like my friend the honourable member for Barton (Mr MCClelland), I wrote to my constituents about this measure because, as I said, I think this legislation as it impacts on our frail aged is the most draconian bit of legislation that I have witnessed as a federal member. I invited my constituents to sign a petition. We have already lodged several hundred of those petitions, and it is taking us a great of time to collate them all. But, overwhelmingly, when people have rung up--and quite a number of them have-they have said, 'Thanks for bringing all this to our attention. We didn't understand it.' It is not just the frail aged who are concerned. Their relatives are concerned about what the impact is going to be on their aunt, their grandmother or their mother. They are horrified. And in my electorate lots of them do not have homes to sell. In conclusion, this is a measure which is going to make a system of health care for the wealthy-they will have no trouble accessing it-but is going to deny the poor and those who have saved for a home their life savings, of which a home is the major part. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: PAIRS
text: It is a pleasure to support the Aged Care Bill that is before the House today. The government is not prepared to accept the amendments that will be moved by the opposition. We certainly had an interesting exercise this morning with motions being moved by the opposition to delay the debate and change the focus of the debate on this bill. It is interesting to note that some of the opposition speakers-the previous speaker,  ed-have referred to this legislation as a draconian measure. It would be fair to say that people in the community are always a little reticent about change, and what is being proposed is a major change from the way we have been used to doing things in the aged care system and the provision of aged care services in Australia. One of the earlier government speakers mentioned the SAM and CAM systems that have been in place. The former government instigated the Gregory report and did not take much notice of it after they did it. This government has recognised a need to reform the provision of aged care services in a sensible way. The previous speaker alluded to some of the peak bodies and the comments they have made. I might draw the opposition's attention to a media release that was put out earlier this year by ANECA, the Australian Nursing deal Homes and Extended Care Association Ltd. In that, the Chief Executive Officer was quoted as saying: Overall, the new aged care legislation delivers incentives for aged care service providers to strive for continuous improvement in care standards and upgrade accommodation standards. Isn't providing a better standard of care for the aged what this debate is all about? The former government's policy revolved around provision of beds. There was an announcement recently of more nursing home bed capacity being available for the Great Lakes area in my electorate. A number of different institutions put in submissions to get that allocation of beds. The focus has been on beds whereas the focus should be on the needs of the people in the community. At the other end of my electorate, in the Hastings area, people who have been assessed through the ACAT team there as needing nursing home care outnumber the number of beds available, and so we have the situation where there are 52 people in the Hastings district on the waiting list to get access to nursing home care. Unfortunately, in regional Australia that quite often means that, until such time as beds become available in the local area, those people have to travel to the city to receive nursing home care. That puts an enormous strain on the family and on the people who need the nursing home care themselves. Recognising this, the government has bitten the bullet in introducing the reforms contained within this legislation to try to address the problems in Australia and the increasing demand-and that is a very important and sobering statistic-for nursing home accommodation as we look towards taking this country through to the tum of the century. I refer to an article which was in the Financial Review earlier this year headed up 'Nursing home plan is sound'. It went on to say: For all the sound and fury emanating from Canberra over the proposed charges for new entrants to nursing homes, the Government's policy is a sensible response to a difficult problem, one that procrastination will only make worse. Procrastination is what we experienced from the former Labor government. This article went on to say: Australia is greying, with the percentage of populacase. tion aged over 65 projected to grow from 11.2 per cent in 1991 to more than 19 per cent by the year 2030. The article went on to say: . . . it is much fairer that people be required to draw on their savings to pay for their own care rather than that they expect taxpayers to do so. "losers" from such an arrangement are, of course, the potential heirs of nursing home residents. But they have no reason either, to demand that taxpayers continue to subsidise nursing home care merely to protect their inheritance. The article went on: But Australians must come to terms with the fact that there is no bottomless well of "government" money. The alternative is taxes to the user-pays principle. This country suffered from that high tax regime for the last 13 years of Labor. The government is taking this opportunity to extend to the nursing home sector what Labor started in the hostels sector of aged care services by way of a user-pays system. Labor's record on aged care is not all that exciting when you look at some of the statistics. Under Labor, 11 per cent of nursing homes did not meet fire standards, 15 per cent of nursing homes did not meet state health standards, and 40 per cent of nursing home patients were sharing rooms with four or more patients. The ALP created a two-tier aged care system. Hostels, with the changes that the former government introduced, were of a good standard because they charged the entry contributions. The nursing homes became increasingly of a poorer standard because they relied on government funding. Dementia patients were not receiving adequate care and funding. The ALP arrived at the last election with a fairly thin policy in this area. The government's reforms aim to provide residents with comfort, dignity and security in their most frail years, give incentives for providers to rebuild and refurbish nursing homes and ensure that access to quality care is based on need, not on means. One of the furphies that has been perpetratecl around the community in this debate has arisen from the Labor Party's putting about the proposition that people with lesser means will not have access to quality care. That will not be the In addition, the reforms will deliver simplicity for providers, make providers more accountable to residents and families and address the capital funding crisis. That is all based on two elements: firstly, accommodaThe tion bonds; secondly, the focus on concessional residents. Concessional residents are those people in the community who cannot afford to pay an accommodation bond. They will still have access to nursing home care. A targeted percentage of the community will get access. Nursing homes must allocate a national average of 27 per cent of beds to financially disadvantaged or concessional residents. Some of the nursing homes in my electorate will probably have a higher percentage of concessional residents than 27 per cent. The flip side of the government's commitment to pay the concessional residents' supplement of $5 per person per day is that there will be an increase in income for a lot of those establishcare ments that have a higher percentage of concessional residents already in their nursing homes. One of those providers has already contacted me, after reviewing the latest information that we have been sending out to the electorate on the reforms in this area, and indicated that they will have an increase. Remember that Labor offered only $3 per day for capital upgrading only to hostels, not to nursing homes, and so there is that balance. There is an equity issue being addressed with the provision of the concessional residents' supplement to nursing home providers; that is, it is the broader tax paying community who should be assisting in the provision of nursing home care to those people in the community who cannot afford to pay the accommodation bonds. That is what this supplement is all about. If it was not there, or if it was of a lesser amount, as Labor had proposed, then the burden of providing that nursing home accommodation to concessional residents would fall mainly on the accommodation bond paying residents in that establishment alone, not on the broader tax paying community. With the $5 concessional residents' supplement being paid by the government, it is the broader tax paying community that is shouldering the responsibility of ensuring that concessional residents, those people who cannot afford to pay the accommodation bond, have access to, and the opportunity for, nursing home care when they need it. When they need it is when they have been through the assessment process with ACAT. As I have said, at one end of my electorate 52 people are on a waiting list to access nursing home care. A lot of those people, because they are in need, will end up spending a period of time in maybe Newcastle or Sydney, a great distance from their loved ones and carers. That is certainly not a satisfactory situation. The issue of equitable access for concessional residents is one that has been raised by the opposition and one on which the government has gone to great lengths to get the message out to the broader community. This government wants people to have access to according to their needs, not their means. That is stated quite clearly in the policy. The Labor Party has been peddling a lot of half-truths and untruths about the financially disadvantaged not being protected. This bill contains stronger protection for these older people than Labor's scheme did. These protections are demonstrated by four key facts, which need to be spelt out very clearly in this debate. One, aged care assessment teams will continue to approve people for entry to care based on their need, not their means. Two, people who cannot afford to pay an accommodation bond will not be asked to pay it, and this will not affect their access to care. Three, every nursing home and hostel will have to take a set number of concessional residents. The target will be 27 per cent of nursing home and hostel residents on average nationally. That will vary from one area to another. Financially disadvantaged areas, which is quite often regional Australia, may have a higher percentage of that. Numbers will be set in each region according to local need, and penalties will apply to providers who do not meet these targets. Four, the government will pay an extra supplement of $5 a day for these residents. This means providers will have a financial incentive to care for their residents, and the burden of providing those places will fall on the broader tax paying community. The broader tax paying community acknowledge that the provision of care for those in need and those financially disadvantaged in the community is a responsibility of the taxpayer and that, equally, people who have the financial means to contribute to their nursing home care have a responsibility to provide that. That falls on the families of people in need as well. It has been clearly set out that there are going to be protections in the legislation for those who are financially disadvantaged, for those pensioners whose only asset is the home, and the spouse is still living in that home. It is very important that we highlight that fact during this debate. Another interesting element that has arisen, particularly in my community, is the level of the accommodation bonds, and I know that in the ruckus here this morning there was mention of a figure of $88,000. I am not sure where the opposition has picked that figure up from, or whether it is an indicative figure of the replacement cost of a nursing home bed, but obviously there is no set ceiling. One nursing home provider in my area, which is a community based organisation, has indicated that it will not be charging an accommodation bond, which is interesting. The other element of that part of the debate is the fact that, although the accommodation bond is paid to the care provider, it is a bond: it is put in trust and will be refunded, less the $2,600 a year over five years, to the person receiving care. So the maximum that is being paid by the resident is $13,000. A lot of people have not come to terms with that and have not understood that because of the misinformation that has been peddled around in that regard. I have gone to great lengths in my electorate to explain that to people. On the subject of the accommodation bonds, the guarantee that must be received about the expenditure of those bonds on improving accommodation must be fairly explicit, and the bill is explicit on this point that amounts derived from the bonds must be used for the service. This is clear and transparent. Furthermore, the bill forges a clear link between accommodation bonds and improvements to accommodation. This link is called certification. To charge an accommodation bond, a service needs to meet certain building and care standards. To demonstrate this, all services will be inspected using an instrument that assesses the building in terms of safety, security, privacy as well as other key points. For the first time, consumers and providers can be confident that a service charging a bond meets appropriate standards. This represents a clear and open benchmark, something that has not existed. The intent is to raise the past standard progressively over time. This means a provider will need to continue investing in their building to make sure he or she can continue to charge bonds. This is a real improvement over Labor's hostel system. Labor did not stop providers charging accommodation bonds for substandard accommodation. Labor did not specify that bonds must be used for the service. This bill will do that and will do it in a measurable way so that we will ensure those standards are kept to and the benchmarks are adhered to. I draw the House's attention to some of the comments that were made by the previous speaker with regard to the support that has come from the peak bodies. He alluded to the fact that there was no support. I mentioned an article in the Financial Review and I mentioned a media release that came from the Australian Nursing Homes and Extended Care Association Ltd. In closing, I will quote from a media release that has come from the National Association of Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals, which is headed 'Structural reforms for aged care mean a better deal for all'. It states: The ... Chief Executive Officer said ... Some strong measures had to be taken to address the urgent capital upgrading needs of nursing homes in order to ensure the future accommodation of Australia's aged. The Government in its legislation has provided more than adequate protection for consumers and through user pay systems surrounding the accommodation bond will ensure funds are available for upgrading for the future. A couple of the peak bodies involved in providing nursing home services in Australia have indicated publicly their support for the reforms. I will finish where I started. Australia, as far as change is concerned, is traditionally a fairly conservative nation. Australians are fairly wary of change. They take their time coming to terms with change, understanding change and getting to understand the benefits that will flow. Over time, the Australian people will come to terms with it. I know this government is proposing a lot of change. We had to after 13 years of a lot of inaction in a number of different areas by Labor both economically and socially. Importantly, this government is focused in this area on providing care based on needs, not means. The financially disadvantaged in our community will certainly have access to the nursing home care that they expect and deserve. We are going to ensure that it will continue into the future on an equitable basis.

Speaker: Mr WILTON
Title: PAIRS
text: I rise today to draw the House's attention to what can only be described as further evidence of the Howard government's abandonment of its responsibilities to the Australian people since the government is abandoning the most vulnerable in our great society-they, of course, being the most sick and the elderly. I rise today to condemn absolutely the government for the introduction of what are no doubt unspecified up-front fees for nursing home patients because this action, coupled with the $577 million in cuts to funding in the 1996 budget, indicates that this government is nothing less than morally bankrupt. The government is embarking on, in my view, nothing less than a wholesale privatisation of the aged care sector. It has no policy direction in this area. It basically has a 'let the market prevail', 'let it rip' type attitude. In doing that, it somehow hopes, perhaps forlornly, that the difficult problems it is not prepared to address will somehow be sorted out by a benevolent private sector. For the elderly residents of Isaacs, of course, I hope that the substance and the guts of this aged care bill, being what they are, cause the bill to fall on its face. I would like briefly to remind the House of the absolutely disastrous situation in which aged care was left the last time the coalition set policy for this sector. In the 26 years of coalition federal government from 1954 to 1983-of course, those three years of cherished Whitlam government interrupted that period of coalition rule-the other side of the House managed to create a system that was nothing less than poorly managed. It was littered with regional inequalities and was badly focused on the provision of nursing beds as opposed to general care issues. Let me briefly offer a summary to the House of the MCLeay report into the aged care sector. The report highlighted the poorly coordinated provision of community based aged care services, which everybody knew about but about which the coalition did nothing. One of the issues identified in the MCLeay report was the absence of a national organisation representing community care groups. While I do not blame the government for this, it is nevertheless a fact and a key issue detailed in the report. The second issue identified in this report was the relative generosity of financial provisions for the construction of nursing homes as compared with community care services. This resulted in an imbalance between community needs and government and private sector provision. The financial disincentive for state governments to involve themselves in the development of community services, which required the state government to match the Commonwealth funding, was a third key factor identified in this MCLeay report, which in some way was indeed much too kind to the coalition for its so-called efforts in policy terms in this key policy area. The report should have said that the coalition has never come up with decent policy in this area. I will refer briefly to the joint review of nursing homes and hostels conducted back in 1986. It was more explicit in its criticism than was the MCLeay report. The joint review identified a number of issues. Among them were the haphazard nature of program development for aged care services, the excessive concentration on institutional care as opposed to community and home based care, and the failure to develop adequate assessment procedures. The fourth issue identified was the lack of coordination between the various levels of government and the fifth and final key issue that this report identified was the inefficiency of the prevailing funding mechanisms. This report highlighted that, in 26 years of federal government, the coalition hardly got anything right. This is not just a slight criticism but a comprehensive repudiation of this government's ability to set policy direction and spend money appropriately. This is nothing less than a joke. I know we have the minister telling us that she is now intending to undertake a major reform process in the area. I can envisage the major industry participants wishing for another term of Labor to sort out the mess that this government is in the process of creating. In the past 29 years, every time there has been a major crisis in aged care services it has required, as in most other policy areas, the introduction of a Labor government to sort the mess out. In extended terms of government, you on that side of the House simply lost the plot in this key policy area. Harking back momentarily to the Whitlam era of 1972 to 1975, at that time Labor had to introduce controls to the expansion of nursing home beds due to what were then massive cost overruns and the over-provision of these services as opposed to hostel and home and community care services. The Whitlam government also had to sort out the many regional inequalities and inequities that those opposite had created prior to the Whitlam government coming to office. In the Hawke-Keating years similarly, the Labor government had to continue its efforts to redress the imbalance between the provision of nursing home beds and hostel places. The Hawke-Keating government had to act to increase the provision of respite beds in hospitals and in nursing homes. It also had to act to increase the provision of home and community care in broadly general terms. It appears that it is always those on this side of the House who historically have had to foot the bill for the incompetence of those opposite--{)r, more correctly, the public has had to foot the bill and those on this side of the House when in government have been the ones who have had to implement the necessary change. We assumed control of an industry which could only be said to be characterised by uncontrolled growth and, simultaneously, uncontrolled cost. It was also characterised by grossly inefficient regulation. Labor increased spending levels during the term of the HawkeKeating government from $1.2 billion in 1985-86 to $2.6 billion in the 1993-94 budget for this key policy area. It would be quite easy for me to go on and on listing Labor's achievements in this field, but I will spare the House because I would like to discuss in some greater detail the bill currently before us. To date, all this government has done in the field of aged care is to rip money out. A list of what I have called K-Mart Costello's cuts includes a cut of $244 million from capital commitments and the removal of $253 million in subsidies from nursing homes for care. This one looks as though it may have some sort of ideological bent in that it will reduce the number of nurses caring for patients. The coalition has also enacted a $72 million saving by introducing user charges for home and community care services. These cuts were reduced in the last budget with the background of the Gregory report, indicating that there was a requirement of capital funding of about $500 million, mainly in the nursing home area. Instead of allocating more funding to the aged care sector, this government in its wisdom decided to remove a further $244 million specifically from capital outlays and introduce a user pays system, as suggested in the National Commission of Audit. This user pays system is obviously poorly directed at meeting the shortfall of 20 per cent in the provision of the home and community care services, as identified in the joint submission by the Australian Health Care Association and others. At the growth rate of some 2.7 per cent per year of persons requiring HACC services, those on this side of the House are looking forward to addressing this shortfall of 40 per cent by the time the Australian public repudiates the initiatives of this mean-spirited coalition. The coalition's alleged justification for introducing this bill includes a couple of key points. The first is the capital shortage identified above and the expectation that a user pays system will furnish the capital funding that is required. The second is that there is some impending prospect of a blowout in the number of persons requiring nursing home beds. That is perhaps difficult to understand when the numbers suggest that the number of people requiring assistance will actually decrease. There will be a decline in those numbers over the forthcoming 10 years. These justifications appear to be nothing less than a beat-up with the specific purpose in mind of simply cutting costs. That path is one that has been well trodden on many occasions before by the federal Treasurer (Mr Costello) and his Victorian counterpart. I want to draw the House's attention to the bill by summarising some of its ill-considered measures. The first of those is an uncapped entry fee for nursing homes with an assets test which includes the family home. As the  out at quite some length, when Labor introduced the assets test, the family home was sacrosanct; the family home was exempt. Over 90 per cent of people entering nursing homes are single. Those entering nursing homes will have to dispose of their house and make other very important decisions whilst they are sick. Furthermore, over 60 per cent of those entering nursing homes arrive from acute hospital care service facilities. You really could not pick a more unfair or worse time to ask people to make such important decisions and to undertake negotiations with the management of these nursing home facilities. Perhaps the minister could have some of her former colleagues provide inhouse advice to sick and infirm people. Another ill-considered measure of this bill is the fact that it provides a formula for the entry fee which potentially will result in all persons having sold their house and being left with $22,500 in assets, with the remainderwhatever that may be-being placed in a trust fund-again, as put quite lucidly by the member for Chifley, at the mercy of solicitors and lawyers who are the trustees of these funds, some of whom on a regular basis are proven to be less than honest in their management of such funds. These funds have no prudential requirements, as the member for Chifley has pointed out. We on this side of the House are expected to trust the same people who appear daily in the newspapers under crime columns having abused the trust that people have placed in them to manage their money honestly. I am sure that the aged, the elderly and the infirm would be even more vulnerable than the majority of Australian society if they placed their money in the hands of unscrupulous solicitors. The third ill-considered measure is the fact that it provides a policy which is supposedly based on the assumption that more capital funds will be available for nursing homes with this up-front fee but with no legislative requirement directing nursing homes to spend money in this particular way. This could potentially be as useless as Mr Howard's savings package because there is no net benefit, as the Secretary to the Treasury quite clearly pointed out yesterday. Another key issue of concern for those on this side of the House is that of a supposedly reformed sector characterised by the growth of a two-tier health care sector-one for the rich and one for the poor. Those places which cannot meet certain standards-that is, those which cater for the poor-will never receive payments for the capital upgrade so they will remain in a poor state. As the shadow minister at the table, the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), has pointed out in her contributions to the House earlier this year, some wings will get orange fruit drink but those funded by the more wealthy health care recipients will receive orange juice. This is a catch-22 situation. Obviously this will affect many members of society. Indeed, it will have a negative impact on the church and those other not for profit providers who are at the forefront of delivering aged care facilities to those most in need and to the needy.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: PAIRS
text: They do it now; you don't understand.

Speaker: Mr WILTON
Title: PAIRS
text: I want to quote an initial comment from Mr Les MACDonald of the Uniting Church New South Wales Synod. He recently stated: I am concerned that the scene is set for the development of a two-tiered aged care system, where those that can pay will have access to excellent, modem facilities and those that can't will be housed in increasingly older and inadequate aged care accommodation. Perhaps the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), who is from the same state as Mr Les MACDonald of the Uniting Church, might keep that quote in mind when he makes a contribution to this debate after me. Another major issue of concern in this bilI is that it has a lack of specified auditing procedures for those involved in providing aged care services. Some of these industry participants are even suggesting a self-audit. One can only think of the potential horrors that programs like A Current Affair and others would be able to televise in that regard. It also facilitates an unspecified ratio of paid to concessional beds which will be needed to be provided by each nursing home. So, obviously people from some suburbs wilI have to search far and wide for a place because of the unknown quota of concessional beds which may have been met in their local area. This heinous and draconian bilI also provides a policy based on the ridiculous premise that nursing homes and hostels provide the same service, a misconception that is still perpetrated by many of those opposite. Hostels are for those persons looking for security and a little assistance in a community environment, while nursing homes arc clearly for the sick. The minister must think they all look like hotel rooms. This bilI is yet another recipe for the coalition to repeat the massive failures it has created so often in the past. It is a government bereft of vision and ideas. It has no direction. Indeed, it is very similar to the voter reaction to Mr Howard which was identified in recent polls by the Bulletin magazine. It will not be long before the coalition parties decide to move on these sentiments and ask 'K-Mart Costello' to fill this massive void. When we return to address these present and future messes-potentially as soon as the next election-we intend to follow the same basic principles outlined dishonestly when the minister introduced the bill to the House. Minister Moylan said on 10 February this year: I circulated a statement entitled 'Steps to Better Care'. This statement detailed the government's commitment to a new era in the provision of residential aged care in this country, based on dignity, comfort and security for all. What we would need to return to, after these vandals have had their go, is the reintroduction of dignity, comfort and security of accommodation to the industry. There are many ways, which the shadow minister has outlined, which show how Labor would do this. Those on this side of the House fully support the work that she has done in this area in challenging a minister who has perpetrated nothing less than a scare campaign and misrepresentation of the true facts. I am sure that the petition opposing this bilI signed by 5,000 members of the electorate of Barton is reflective of the true views of modem Australia.(Time expired)

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: PAIRS
text: Mitchell) (1.03 p.m.)There is one thing I cannot understand about the Labor Party's attitude in this debate. If the Aged Care Bill 1997 is so bad, so crook and so oppressive for the elderly and the aged around Australia, why don't they just let it go through both houses and let the government reap the whirlwind? Surely that would be a tactic-providing they make all the claims and the statements they are making now, making sure that they are covered-to allow this process to go through without change or amendment. I invite the shadow minister at the table, the honourable member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), if she is serious, to consider that process. I do believe that it is not really the opinion of the Australian Labor Party that this thing is so bad after all. Otherwise, why would they be delaying, why would they be attempting to put back this program, using all the techniques of the House and the Senate to delay and set aside legislation that is sorely needed for the care of the aged in Australia? I do believe that their real purpose, their real goal, is not one that they are saying. I know that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, are a very direct and straightforward individual, that you would not be ensnared by a process such as this. But I do have to bring to the attention of the House the fact that I consider the comments and the tactics of the Australian Labor Party to be dishonourable. They are not honest in the way in which they are handling this process. The shadow minister at the table and the opposition are using the processes of the House of Representatives and the Senate to have the introduction of sorely needed change delayed. If they were serious in their criticisms, if their concerns were justified and could be demonstrated and if all of the statements of the shadow minister, to every 'i' and to every '1' , proved to be exact, then this is an horrific piece of legislation that no person of conscience or compassion would want to foist on the aged people of Australia. Therefore, they would want the Australian people to see how heartless and thoughtless the current government is by allowing the process to be enacted. But no, that is not what they are doing. They are not allowing this process to be enacted. They are not allowing these processes that they consider heartless and poorly thought through to be implemented. They want to make changes. They want to debate for hours. They want to have the Senate go on for years with committees and all sorts of processes to get, they say, this legislation right. I do not believe that is the true motive of the Australian Labor Party. The true motive of the Australian Labor Party is a backward looking process, and because of the shadow minister's previous professional involvement with the formulation of policy, she just wants to stick with the past. She does not want to make changes. She wants to say, 'What we did 18 months ago was right. What we did five years ago was right. What we did 10 years ago was right.' If the opposition were a constructive organisation in its approach to this process, it would adopt constructive approaches. But its approaches are not constructive; they are destructive and delaying. So I put it to the House that the opposition, instead of wishing to see changes made for the benefit of the elderly, are using the elderly, in this instance, as a political ploy, a political process, to suit the goals and objectives of the Australian Labor Party. The complaints; the statements of how poorly constructed this legislation is; what terrible consequences it is going to have for people who are in aged care facilities or who are contemplating going into aged care facilities: surely these must be exaggerations. Otherwise, there would be a more constructive approach to getting results from the Australian Labor Party or, on the other hand, they would let this legislation through and let the government reap the whirlwind. I want to tum to the details of the legislation because the government has adopted a twofold approach. I think it is imaginative and suits the needs of the elderly. It is a process which provides certainty and funding. The two streams of activity are these: first of all, to bring a consistency and simplicity of administration and provision of care without confusion and without difficulty to aged people, that is, by consolidating the nursing home accommodation with hostel accommodation and letting the assessment of a person's condition or needs be the sole criterion about what sort of accommodation they would receive. The Australian Labor Party, when they came to office, had, they said, too many nursing homes. So what they did was to not fund nursing homes but to fund hostels. That became difficult and expensive so they then allowed hostels to extend the services that they offered and the hostels of today are more like the nursing homes of 10 and 15 years go because they are allowed to do practically anything. The average length of stay in a nursing home today is six months. They are places where people really just spend the last few months of their lives. They are not there in the true sense as nursing homes, but because of the pressure of funding on the Labor Party governments over a period of time, they had to reclassify the activities of both nursing homes and hostels. So nursing homes became places where people were almost at the point of terminal illness-very ill indeed. One would hope that many people come out of those nursing homes well, or at least better, but the fact is that on average they stay there six months before they die. Hostels have become places where the treatment and care that are given are similar to that formerly given in nursing homes. Care for the aged was a budget driven process; the decisions that were made were purely budget driven. That was the way the Labor Party administered care for the aged; that was the result of their activities. Paul Keating was all about budget driven stuff-pulling the levers, getting the figures, having glasses overflow and bringing home the bacon. That was the Keating style of operation. We are changing that. We are saying that you cannot be an artificial division. Let us identify the problems that people have and give them the appropriate treatment at the appropriate level. What could be more sensible and better geared to the needs of individuals than that? That is the first step. The second step-the second stream of activity-is to assist people where possible to deal with their increasing age in their own home. Here I refer to what I think is a far-sighted program: community aged care packages. People are provided with what amounts to hostel care by professionals in their own homes. This is going beyond what is considered domiciliary nursing care-somebody blowing in for an hour or two to help somebody wash or to administer their medicine or to have the community aid person come round and clean their house. It goes beyond that. The assistance provided through the community aged care packages will be personal care, shopping, housework, laundry, lawn mowing, after hours emergency care, meal preparation, monitoring medications, bill paying, minor maintenance, assistance with transport to medical appointments, and respite care. Those are some of the services that CACPs are offering. That is a comprehensive service akin to being in a motel. It is akin to being in a hostel, yet you have the backup of professional services. The largest single provider of CACPs happens to be in my electorate: the Anglican Retirement Villages. They are a fine organisation. It is all very well for members of the Australian Labor Party to say, 'The poor won't get looked after,' and ask, 'What are your prudential arrangements and how do you coordinate the whole thing?' They are obviously completely unaware of how things actually work. The Baptist homes trust-I know my friend at the table, the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles), would have some familiarity with them, and with the Anglican Retirement Villages-are a most ethical and caring organisation. They are working on the internal cross-subsidy process right now. People who can afford it pay; those who cannot do not pay. That is exactly what the caring institutions of Australia are running now. But it is going to be formalised by the process that the government is using. It can easily be done, and those compassionate and worthwhile organisations are doing it, so why should everybody not do it? That is what the minister is saying. Why should the wealthy not pay for the poor in their retirement-what is strange about that?-and in the provision of capital input, the buildings and backup services that are needed. Until a person reaches that point, the process is there of providing community aged care right in their home in an extended way which more resembles the hostels of old. People are more comfortable staying in their own home. They would prefer, right to the ultimate, to stay in their own home. They would prefer to have the freedom of inviting their families at weekends. They would prefer the independence that being in their own home offers. In many instances in the past under Labor policies services were not provided in the home. People were forced to sell their homes because they could not get the care they needed in their own home. We are saying, 'We will give you care in your own home. We will help you have a dignified aged lifestyle. We will assist you with all the backup services we can offer by professionals.' If they have the assets, people can then sell their house and move in when it is necessary. If not, they will receive exactly the same care as they do now in the Baptist retirement trust or the Anglican Retirement Villages-the same care a wealthy person receives. You cannot tell the differences between people. Nobody knows the differences in people's means unless they themselves disclose it to their neighbours in those villages. Nobody knows because the quality of service is identical no matter what your means, no matter what your background. The shadow minister advances spurious arguments about second-class care. For goodness sake! What scurrilous arguments you bring into this place. You do not do your profession any credit by the way in which you are arguing this matter. You ought to be ashamed of the way in which you are scaring old people with nonsense arguments. A true professional in this circumstance would want to get results, not score political points. You are scoring political points and causing delays and problems. I have given you the solution: be constructive and get results or let the stuff go through and let the government cop the whirlwind. But you will not do either of those things, you would rather play politics. I am arguing now that you stop playing politics and let us get on with the business of providing decent care for aged people. Let us look at what the government is proposing here: proper care, professionally supported, in a person's home for as long as they are able to remain there. And then professional assessment of what care they need before they move into the next stage of their aged care-whether it be hostel accommodation or nursing home accommodation. The type of care will be different and will suit the person's need, but an assessment will be made of the process. We had a stunt in the parliament this morning with the shadow minister trying to run a whole lot of arguments about where all the shortfalls were. I just want to reiterate some of the facts in the way in which this new aged care process is going to operate. Firstly, aged care assessment teams will continue to approve people for care based on their needs, not on their means. That is not and never has been in the government's mind; in fact, it is not in operation in most decently run nursing or retirement facilities at the moment throughout Australia. Certainly the largest ones do not operate on the basis of means but on the basis of needs. That is the tradition. You denigrate the tradition of nursing and hostel care in Australia by your arguments. Secondly, people who cannot afford to pay an accommodation bond will not be asked to pay it and that will not affect their access to care either. Those are the statements; that is the way it works now, and that is the way it is going to work in the future. But the fact of the matter is that those who do have resources are going to help pay for those who do not. That is where the extra money is going to come from which you could not find as a government, and which the Gregory report so clearly enunciated. You went down the gurgler. The whole thing declined. You had a maintenance attitude in this area. Just maintain the system. Do not worry about any improvements or changes. Let it gradually degenerate with the processes of age to the buildings, facilities and services being provided. There has been no imagination or new policies whatsoever. Every nursing home and hostel will have to take a set number of concessional residents. There is protection built in by the legislation. If they want to take more, they can. If they will not take the number required, they will be asked or required to. So there is protection there. If the bottom line is the formula, then the legislation does provide for that. It underscores and sets in concrete, if you like, the already existing practice. The government has made the commitment that if there is an extra cost it will pay it. That is broadly what is necessary. What about the prudential requirements of these organisations holding bond funds and those sorts of things? If people are required to make a payment going in, and when they come out there is a release of that bond, what is the protection going to be for their funds? That is a legitimate and proper question. But it is not the spurious stuff that the shadow minister has come up with that there is no protection. First of all, there will be a requirement on facilities to maintain a certain level of assets in liquid form so the bonds can be repaid to residents as they leave. What is unusual about that? Every insurance company does it. Every bank does it. They have got to be able to pay you when you go in and ask for your money. The operators of nursing homes or retirement villages will be asked to do the same thing; they will be required to do the same thing. An industry fund will be established-that is right across Australia-which, with providers, will pay a portion of the bonds. This fund will act as a lender of last resort should a provider's own liquidity prove to be insufficient. So there is a second protection. And, as a third protection, there will be insurance as well. So you have got a prudential fund established by the provider, then you have got an industry-wide fund which will be a lender of last resort, and behind that insurance again. I do not think the Reserve Bank has got so much protection. I certainly know that building societies in Australia do not. I know that credit unions do not. You are looking at something that is safer than credit unions, safer than banks, and you are going to be critical of that process. Get real! You are just exaggerating and causing concern when there should not be concern. What about the classification of people? Maybe that is a worry-what sort of service will I get? Anybody who is currently in either a nursing home or a hostel will continue with the classification they have now. That will not change. Over a period of 12 months, assessments will be made. Is the care appropriate to your needs? What person or family would not want an elderly individual in a nursing home or a hostel assessed on that basis? Is the care appropriate to your needs? Not to your means but to your needs. Is the care adequate is the real question being asked, and if it is not it will be changed. Is there anything wrong with us saying, 'Let's check to see how people are being cared for'? For goodness sake, they did it with child care throughout Australia. There was an incredible mess created by the previous government on the accreditation process. The thought police were out about what could be put into preschools and what could not be put into preschools. Yet are they objecting to this process? Do they not like it or do they think it is strange? I think this is a weird process that we are into here. I will just call once more on the Australian Labor Party to reassess their stance. If you think this is so objectionable, let it go through and let the government wear the pain. Otherwise, change your attitudes and let us have some constructive activity from you.

Speaker: Mr ANDREN
Title: PAIRS
text: If there is one piece of recent legislation that has caused concern, debate and apprehension in the community, it is this Aged Care Bill. This bill attempts to bring about the most significant changes to aged care in Australia since the Menzies government introduced the first federal act of parliament relating to aged care in 1954-namely, the Aged Persons Homes Act. That act was not so much about aged care as about provision of adequate housing for service men and women after the Second World War and the Korean War.
