This bill will, if passed unamended, allow for nursing home and hostel programs to be rolled together into a single funded residential aged model; provision of a single assessment model to replace the two systems that exist currently in nursing home and hostel programs; extension of the existing entry contribution system in hostels to accommodation bonds for all high-dependency residential care; certification and accreditation of facilities, services and providers with the minimum acceptable benchmark being gradually increased as the existing infrastructure improves; standardisation of basic fee levels; extension of the user-pays principles; and increased quality of residential aged care services. In the words of the Churches of Christ homes, 'These times are exciting for aged care.' 'Each of the aims of the bill,' according to the organisation, 'is an admirable, desirable and achievable aim.' So why the concern? While the aims of this bill are admirable, its promotion and explanation to the elderly of Australia have been poorly handled. This is in no way a criticism of the minister, who I have found to be caring and receptive to any views that I have put forward on the peculiar issues pertaining to the legislation that impact on my electorateincluding, as it does, large regional centres with an established nursing home component and very small rural communities with nursing home type accommodation in local hospitals. The problem with dissemination of information began with the draft bill, a copy of which I received the week submissions were due and which was hardly of much use to local aged care assessment teams or service providers. The same unfortunately occurred with the exposure draft of the principles, received after the due date for comments. Is it too much to expect every member to receive copies of such contentious bills and accompanying information at a reasonable time before such submissions are due? Perhaps the peak bodies advising the aged care industry are at fault here by keeping the input and feedback at an executive level. The minister was alert to the concerns about a feeling of being left out by sections of the community, particularly in rural areas, and accepted late submissions from my electorate. For that I am grateful because it led to the retention of the dementia care counselling service funded by this government and administered by the Alzheimers Association. That kind of special attention to particular concerns has been greatly appreciated in the Orange district especially, where a bureaucratic pen stroke was set to eliminate a service that was, and is, a lifeline for carers of dementia loved ones in their own homes. But I am greatly disturbed that in the case of the Yeoval Hospital multipurpose centre, which is a model for aged care for smaller communities, I believe, the department has yet to get back to the board of that organisation, despite assurances to me in early April that they would explain the path Yeoval Hospital should take in both its hostel and nursing home care. The hospital has decided unilaterally-because the reforms will not be implemented until October-to go down the path of certification for its hostel but to seek recurrent funding for its nursing home, having entered into an agreement, and to wait for more details, which are yet to be provided. This is the sort of lack of communication that is upsetting for the carers of the rural aged. So when I support this bill in the comments I make today, I certainly do not support the manner in which it has been explained to some key sections of the community. It is a pity there has been confusion out there in the community because I believe the system the government has come up with is far simpler and fairer than aged care policies in the past. We have heard the minister detail the results of the survey into the aged care sector-the homes that did not meet fire standards or health standards and the number of patients in a four-bed, or more, ward. We have read the figures of experts who believe it will take $125 million a year to bring the nursing home infrastructure up to standard. The coalition is quick to accuse the former government of overseeing minimum standards and having no long-tenn plan, especially for dementia care. But, as I said, had I not raised the threatened loss of dementia counsellors in rural areas-through the concerns of the Orange Aged Care Assessment Team and the carers out there-then this service would have gone and it would have been inadequately mainstreamed through home and community care, which is ill-equipped for such a service. Overall, though, I believe the bill and its principles do provide a new and a fair system of aged care, and that is why I support these refonns. I am aware that many in the community might question why they have to pay an accommodation bond when others do not. Unless we access funds from the assets of those who can afford to pay, then we will not have a nursing home system of any quality. I have been concerned at the failure of the government to apply a cap on accommodation bonds. The minister's office tells me that there is no need, that the hostel system has worked without a bond quite satisfactorily and that there will be little need for hostels or nursing homes to charge more than a reasonable amount, given the prudential arrangements in place. The minister argues that if a capping mechanism was put in place, then bonds could be higher than necessary and any interest obtained from bonds must be used exclusively for aged care. However, it is interesting to note that, under section 57-12 of the bill, there is an additional subsection to the original draft-namely, subsection (1), clause (c)-which allows for the minister to invoke the user rights principIe, which sets an upper limit on bonds. So there is the mechanism to control bonds at the minister's discretion, according to the interpretation of the bill that I have received. That is good and it is essential. There will be a national average of 27 per cent of places for concessional clients-those on pensions. I am told this could mean as low as five per cent concessional places in some areas and as high as 85 per cent in others. I wonder how the department will keep track of that average of 27 per cent. It sounds a bit like the promise to cut small business red tape by 50 per cent. How do we know when we get there? There must always be a way of providing for those in the community who need aged care, but who can afford to contribute only a small amount or nothing at all. I will be watching this aspect closely as these changes take effect. Mr Deputy Speaker, there has been much concern in the community about the perceived need for nursing home clients to sell their homes to afford an accommodation bond. I believe there has been an unnecessary degree of fear generated by this perception, and I draw the attention of the House to the fact that, currently, 55 per cent of hostel or nursing home occupants choose to sell their family home to enter such a facility. If there is a spouse, partner or, indeed, a carer living in the home, it does not come under the assets test because it remains the family home. I found the comments recently of one correspondent in the Sydney Morning Herald a little hard to swallow. She claimed that many part-pensioners, particularly those in Sydney or Melbourne, will complain when they discover the forced sale of their homes makes them ineligible for a pension. Mr Deputy Speaker, if someone is so lucky as to capitalise on the property boom in Sydney, especially at the moment, and pays an accommodation bond in a hostel or nursing home and is still up to $700,000 better off in the bank, why in heaven's name should they qualify for the pension anyway? It is not an inheritance tax; it is payment for accommodation and care at an advanced age. From what I have studied in this bill, the explanatory notes, the Bills Digest and elsewhere, I think this legislation is fair and will achieve the goals pointed out by the Churches of Christ Homes to which I alluded earlier in my comments. I am reassured by comments from the minister that full pensioners will pay no more than the basic pensioner contribution, and will pay no further income tested charge. The base fee for part-pensioners of $21.10 plus 25c in every dollar of income over $49 a week appears fair enough. However, aged care providers have contacted me with concerns that concessional residents will have only about $1,500 left to spend annually after statutory fees and charges are met. This $1,500 has to proyide for clothing, toiletries, telephones, stamps, entertainment, newspapers, hairdressing-perhaps cigarettes and alcohol-gifts, pharmaceuticals and, maybe, taxis. It does not seem a lot for those expenses, does it? Perhaps it does need revisiting. Mr Deputy Speaker, this Aged Care Bill and its complementary bills comprise one of the most complex pieces of legislation to enter this parliament in many years. I therefore am not prepared to commit myself totally to it, because it may very well have a series of landmines that I have not picked up. But we need to restructure aged care in this country, given the statistics staring us in the face of the size of the aged sector in 20 to 30 years time. We could go a long way to funding much of that aged care infrastructure if we were to properly reform our tax system. The Treasurer (Mr Costello) said in the House yesterday that the cash economy was of grave concern-or words to that effect. Forgone taxes in this country are a national budgetary disgrace. We cannot afford vital public infrastructure funds for hospitals, nursing homes, highways and railways because we are being ripped off and the poor old PA YE bunny is footing the bill. In the absence of any political will to reform the tax system and obtain the revenue we should be recovering, we must make a start on rebuilding and improving the aged care accommodation in this country, and lifting the standards of care. It will cost a huge amount of dollars. This users pay system is the only way we can go at the moment, so short is the lead time before the aged population crisis hits us. However, there are real concerns out there still, some of which I have outlined. I would like to add a few more-these from a hostel accommodation provider in Blayney. The board of the Lee Hostel tells me the program for implementation is unrealistic, that current funding agreements with the Commonwealth are effectively ended because it is now either a recurrent funding or accommodation bond arrangement. They and the Yeo val multipurpose hospital service I earlier referred to believe the recurrent funding arrangement they have entered into with the government should remain intact and still allow them to access the accommodation bonds option. I notice there are provisions for rural and remote services to ensure people stay in their communities for continuous care from hostel to nursing home. I applaud that. I think there remains a high degree of misunderstanding, though, in some rural areas and I would urge the department to ensure smaller country towns, in particular, are aware of the recurrent funding option and what their options are in terms of charging accommodation bonds. This also requires an early settlement between the states and Commonwealth on the respective status of nursing home type accommodation in smaller country hospitals. Much also has been made of the subsidy of $5 a day per concessional resident, with the opposition suggesting that this alone would be the amount of Commonwealth support for such clients, as far as I can ascertain from comments. I think I heard the minister's adviser right when he assured me this is not correct. I am concerned that Aged Care Australia believes this concessional resident supplement should be at least $12 a day if the objective of improving buildings and infrastructure is to be met. But I am also persuaded by the figures of the previous administration that show the supplement equivalent was but $3. This came about when the former government allocated $10 million a year on its tiered system standard aggregated modu1e-or $3 a day per resident-for capital upgrade. The new arrangements will provide $5 a day, I am told, in addition to the $100 a day current subsidy. It is an additional supplement that will assist the provider's capital requirements. Nursing homes and hostels which take more than their set number of concessional residents will still receive full funding for them. I hope they are right. As well, Aged Care Australia questions the cost of the accreditation agency yet to be established. Whatever the cost will be, I presume it will be established and will perform the necessary task allotted it under the legislation. The bill provides for three types of aged care: residential, community and flexible. I particularly applaud the resources being put into provision of home based care. It seems a sensible restructuring of the industry and the demands for aged care services. I only hope the government and the minister continue to listen to the community in the months leading up to the October start-up, which still seems too early. Can I plead also for the government to look at other aged care options out there in the community such as that provided by the Abbeyfield Society. This organisation falls outside the residential, community and flexible care categories of this bill. However, it provides about 25 homes at this stage around Australia, including one in Orange, that offer a sharing, virtually self-care accommodation for elderly folk, with a major, almost exclusive, voluntary local committee to run them. They are seeking $175,000 a year to maintain their Melbourne based administration. The homes run themselves virtually, free up the scarce rental accommodation that the clients may otherwise occupy, but offer a cooperative community based elderly residential facility for pensioners. It is highly cost-effective accommodation for our elderly people who are not ready for hostel or nursing home care, but who require companionship and community care if needed. I urge the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) to consider Abbeyfield in her interpretation of flexible aged care under this bill. Mr Deputy Speaker, this is a radical change in aged care, there is no doubt. Its consequential provisions that amend existing legislation bear testimony to the complexity of the changes. I only hope the government has got it right. I have a gut feeling that it has, but there is much fine tuning and allaying of concerns yet to be done, particularly as we are dealing with one of the two most vulnerable sectors of the community-the frail aged. With those reservations and cautions, I commend these bills to the House. Miss JACKIE KELLY (Lindsay) 0.39 p.m.)-I rise in support of the government's Aged Care Bill and commend the initiatives outlined in the bill to the residents of the Lindsay electorate. I would like to reiterate the words of the member for Calare (Mr Andren), a true Independent in this place, who has examined the actions of the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) and the bill and cannot find fault with it but retains some reservations. Those reservations mainly come from the scaremongering by Labor. It is important that I reassure the residents, staff and proprietors of the three hostels and four nursing homes in my electorate who will benefit directly from the measures of this bill. They are: the Emmaus Village Hostel; the Edinglassie Hostel; the Lemongrove Gardens Hostel; the Edinglassie Nursing Home; the Governor Phillip Nursing Home; the Henry Fulton Nursing Home; and the Mountainview Nursing Home. All have a proud tradition and reputation for the delivery of quality care to the aged in the Lindsay electorate. The passage of this bill will provide greater incentive and opportunity to them in the future. It is well known that: our population is ageing-it is estimated that by the year 2030, 20 per cent of our population will be over 65; the current aged care system is in crisis and does not have the capacity to meet the needs of our ageing population; and Labor's neglect of the nursing home sector was a shameful act that consigned too many people to a life in substandard accommodation with little choice or dignity. This government's aged care policy initiatives are essential to address the failure of Labor's two-tiered aged care system-a system that has seen individuals in nursing homes forced to accept second-best accommodation in facilities that have been poorly funded and neglected by 13 years of Labor government. We have heard much of Labor's cynical scaremongering campaign over the past months that has totally focused on promoting misinformation and hollow rhetoric, while deliberately scaring older people in our communities and their families--especially in the electorate of Lindsay. The shadow minister, the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), has made a number of unsubstantiated comments which have caused the residents of Lindsay considerable concern. She attacks our policies but has no vision of her own to put forward alternatives which will take us into the 21 st century. Labor's policy in relation to aged care is simply promising to deliver more of the same poor quality, substandard nursing home accommodation. Members of the previous Labor government sat on their hands and ignored the recommendation of Professor Gregory's 1995 report that found that '$124 million per annum needs to be spent to bring nursing home infrastructure up to an acceptable level'. Labor abdicated their responsibility to care for the aged into the future in 1995, they ignored aged care policy during the 1996 federal election campaign and now they offer no vision for the future-simply grannie bashing and scaremongering. It must be remembered that the shadow minister, who now professes great concern for the welfare of our older citizens, was a consultant to the previous Labor minister, who failed his responsibility to the aged. The member for Jagajaga was clearly a failure then and her lack of policy alternatives now indicates that nothing has changed. Throughout the development of this reform package, the government has undertaken a thorough assessment of the needs of the aged in our community. Some aspects of the existing hostel system have been retained and extended into the nursing home sector. The extension of the hostel entry contribution system to nursing homes will provide a much needed source of capital to overcome, for the first time in 10 years, the capital crisis that has bedevilled the nursing home sector. This will be achieved by asking those in the community who have the ability to do so to make a greater contribution to the cost of their care than they do at present. There is no need for a cap. To reassure the member for Calare, if some senior residents who can afford it wish to have gold taps, shagpile carpets and hot and cold running jacuzzis, then they are welcome to it and will pay the costs accordingly. But any home that caters to that style of accommodation must still maintain the concessional resident quota. I think competition-a great principle of our party and a great Liberal tradition-can prove that exactly what has happened in the hostel system will occur again in the homes. It is also important at this point to counter Labor's irresponsible scaremongering, suggesting that individuals will be forced to sell their homes to access an aged care facility. Nothing could be further from the truth. This has been reiterated by the minister and nearly every member speaking on this side of the House. Protections have been included for individuals with dependent children, carers and spouses. No-one will be forced to sell the family home. I think it is very important to make that point: no-one will be forced to sell the family home. Once no-one is living in it, then it is hardly a family home. It can be rented; it becomes an asset and gets included in anyone's eligibility for a pension. Pensioners whose income test is less than the pension, plus the free amount of $49, will not be affected by the income test arrangements. Accommodation bonds will not be on all residents and prudential arrangements have been made to protect any bonds that are put up. It is important to reassure people that those bonds we are talking about are not astronomical fees. We are talking about $2,600 a year to a maximum of five years. After that no further draw-downs from the bonds can be made. The introduction of accommodation bonds and income testing will ensure that the government's resources are focused to the advantage of the less fortunate in our communities. They will be complemented by the concessional resident quota and a concessional resident subsidy. Under the new accommodation bond arrangements, the maximum contribution any individual will be required to pay is $13,000 over five years. It must be emphasised that the government will still make a substantial contribution to the costs of aged care of all people. Our ageing population will rightly demand higher quality nursing home accommodation and care than has been available in the past. The bill that we are debating today provides the foundation for the delivery of an aged care service that provides access to care based on needs, not means-a standard that meets or exceeds world's best practice. For the first time, the level of government subsidy for each resident will be based on the degree of frailty of the resident according to their needs and not according to the style of accommodation occupied, their means. The measures in this bill not only provide a plan for the future but deliver immediate benefits to the l30,000 residents in hostels and nursing homes today. The new residents classification scale will allow more choice and flexibility for older people. It also ensures that funding follows an individual's care needs. The government's commitment to ageing is enhanced by the measures in this bill. It will enable people to stay in familiar surroundings near their family and friends as their care needs change. It is an integrated package that will deliver quality care for our older citizens and provide dignity and choice for all. The new Aged Care Bill will complement other programs that support older people in our communities, such as the home and community care and the community aged care packages. In implementing this package, the government has ensured that those in our community with limited means will be assured access to aged care services. The 27 per cent concessional resident quota and the concessional resident subsidy will ensure adequate support to maintain aged care facilities in less affluent areas. This is an important consideration in the Lindsay electorate, which is a traditional lower to middle income family area. During the 1996 election campaign, the government promised increased assistance for people with dementia. This bill delivers on that commitment. For the first time, mental frailty will gain better recognition and weighting in the residential classification scale. This scale provides funding on the basis of needs arising from incapacities. Under Labor, only physical incapacities were subsidised. Under the new funding system contained in this bill, subsidies for mental incapacity will be substantially increased. In some instances, residents in aged care establishments who require intensive supervision because of dementia will receive funding increases in excess of 30 per cent. The government's new aged care reforms will simplify procedures for providers and provide incentives for the investment in world-class aged care facilities. Importantly, red tape and bureaucracy will be slashed. Unwieldy bureaucracy will be replaced by peer driven review processes that are responsi ve to the needs of residents, providers and others in the industry and, most importantly, promote the development of leading edge technology and world's best practice. Members opposite continue to criticise the government's aged care reforms. We make no apologies for moving so quickly to ensure that our elderly people can reside in aged care facilities with dignity, comfort and security. This bill represents the first step of this government's ongoing commitment to ensuring the provision of quality aged care services and facilities to our older citizens. It is esting to note that the member for Calare has reservations, but he has examined the bill and he sees it as an enormous improvement on previous legislation and previous conditions in the industry. We will continue to improve in this industry. The Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) has a grasp on her portfolio that shows vision and funding right through to all of the considerations and concepts that could possibly affect our aged population through to the year 2030. I congratulate the minister on presenting a comprehensive and integrated package that addresses Labor's failures and enhances the ability of the aged care sector to meet the challenges of our aged population. The minister came to the portfolio with limited experience in aged care, having previously been the shadow minister for small business. She has shown her aptitUde, her enthusiasm and her ability to get around complex procedures in industry in a very short space of time. She has listened to industry. She has responded to what has been required in this area that has been neglected for 13 years. Members opposite continue to run significant scare campaigns in this area. They have challenged our government over issues such as the enormous accommodation bonds that they say will be required. Let me assure the residents of Lindsay that this will not be so. There is no limit on what accommodation bonds can be charged. It is purely up to you in terms of the style of accommodation that you seek to access. The industry will provide a vast range of accommodation levels to meet different lifestyles. Our government's commitment to the aged has not wavered at all over the last 14 months. Over the next 14 months leading to the next electionMr Andrew Thomson-Fourteen years. Miss JACKIE KELLY-Over the next 14 years we will be challenging the leading edge technology in this industry. It is a tremendous challenge that we are all rising to meet. We are urging the industry to build better buildings, to start competing, and that is an important aspect in my electorate of Lindsay where we have a limited number of hostels but a inter- high demand. We have a number of young families who wish to have their parents close by. Quite frequently, grandparents have to be settled far away from the electorate of Lindsay, which is a brand new electorate. We have got very new housing estates, such as Glenmore Park, Claremont Meadows and Mount Pleasant, which are booming with a number of new families and first home buyers who have had to move to western Sydney because of the dramatic rise in accommodation costs in the inner city. They have left behind parents who have access to aged care hostels in those areas but not in western Sydney. It is an increasing concern because it also adds to the breakdown between the older generation and the younger generation. When children grow up too far away from their grandparents they tend to have less tolerance for the elderly. The elderly themselves develop a fear of young people. They tend to see three young people in a group and think it is a gang. A great schism occurs in our society. I think it is important to keep relationships through all generations open and flowing. It is important to place aged care homes in electorates such as Lindsay where there is access to the grandchildren and sometimes the great-grandchildren. As the young grow up there is no fear of getting old. There is no fear of the unknown. They have a great amount of respect for their grandparents and extended family. Currently over 40 per cent of residents nursing homes share rooms with three or more people. Eleven per cent of the facilities do not meet fire standards. Fifteen per cent not meet health standards. That does not apply to any of the homes in my electorate, because they are all relatively new. They are all of an excellent standard but there is a shortage of them. With this introduction of accommodation bonds we will see the potential for new homes to open up. Groups like the Moran Group are gearing up to take advantage of what can be done in the industry and to start providing some competition, some choice, some diversity and some varied standards of accommodation to meet the increasingly particular needs of the generation of the baby boomers, who tend to be more demanding in terms of services offered accommodation type. It is important to come back to Professor it! Gregory's report, which in 1995 identified a deficit in the aged care area. Labor's best response was worth only $36.4 million over four years. What is worse, they actually funding for capital. This is at a stage where nursing homes do not have elevators between floors, do not meet fire standards and are positive health risks. In 1992-93, $45 million was available for nursing home capital alone. This bill addressMarch es the need that Professor Bob Gregory stated was required, of $125 million annually. We are making inroads into the capital investment in our aged care homes and nursing care records. In 14 months we have gone a lot further down the track than Labor had gone in 13 years. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr SOMLYAY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Treasurer. It is also about the national accounts. What are the implications of today's national accounts for growth in the coming year? What is the significance of the fact that all areas, apart from stocks, contributed to growth in the March quarter?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Today's national accounts show that the Australian economy grew strongly in the March quarter by 0.9 per cent, a good outcome, and pointed at very favourable prospects in 1997-98. With the exception of stocks, all areas of expenditure contributed to growth. Forward indicators of housing activity confirmed that the housing recovery continues. Domestic final demand and exports grew very rapidly-domestic final demand by 2.1 per cent and exports by 2.5 per cent. If it had not been for the run-down in stocks, the quarter would have shown an increase substantially in excess of one per cent and, even in the event that stocks are unchanged in the June quarter, stocks will add one percentage point to GDP(E) growth for that quarter. the stock to sales ratio, which is very low, indicates that while sales were strong for the quarter there was an unexpected run-down in stocks. As a result, you would expect in the June quarter a rebuilding of stocks, which will contribute to a very strong outcome for the June quarter. If you wanted to get a set of national accounts which would show favourable prospects, these are the kinds of accounts that you would want. These are the kinds of accounts where you see a growth in private final demand and in exports. Coming off a low stocks figure, it will be a very good outcome in June. Indeed, that is totally consistent with the government's forecasts for strengthening growth in 1997-98.

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: It is a one-horse race. To come back to the national accounts: 0.9 per cent growth in the March quarter; all of the indicators in relation to private final demand, strong; the only detraction from growth, stocks; a sales to stock ratio which run down and which will be corrected; a contribution from stocks which will take the current quarter to one per cent and above; strengthening growth; low inflation growth; low interest rate growth. They are the kinds of conditions that you would actually want to see in the Australian economy. I think the only people who will be upset about today's national accounts will be the Labor Party, because the Labor Party take great delight when things go badly. Seeing a good result and favourable conditions will of course be of no interest to the Labor Party today. Mr Speaker, you would be aware that yesterday the Leader of the Opposition threatened some of his frontbenchers over their treachery. Today we find out that he is proposing discussion of a matter of public importance on the economy. We on this side have seen this before. When the leader comes into do the MPI, it indicates that it is about time to try to buoy up the troops. The Australian said that the Leader of the Opposition 'made it clear' to the Labor Party meeting yesterday 'that he did not mind if the message was passed on to those who were unable to attend'. Then the Australian says, 'Those absent from the meeting included MPs Lindsay Tanner, Mark Latham and Kim Carr.' The member for Melbourne is not here and the member for Werriwa is, but I have said it before: they are the face of modernising Labor and they should be listened to by the leadership. They should not be cast aside; they are the face of modernising Labor. They have a few economic ideas and they should be allowed to ask questions, too. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders: Stolen Children

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Has the minister seen reports of comments made in an international forum that were critical of Australia's response to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission inquiry into the removal of Aboriginal and is Torres Strait Islander children from their families? What is the minister's response to these comments?

Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for his question. I have seen comments by Mr Mick Dodson made in the United States. I have not seen the fuIl text of what he said, so I can only comment on how I have seen it reported. I have to say that what I have seen reported is very disappointing and I ask why is Mr Dodson overseas focusing on only the negatives of what is happening and not focusing on some of the good things that are happening. It is very important in this debate that there is some balance and some capacity to say that good things are happening as well. In my own area of health, that is, that I have direct responsibility for, there are some very positive things happening. We have framework agreements with six out of eight states and territories to bring Aboriginal people to the negotiating table-to bring ATSIC and the Commonwealth, state and territory governments and Aboriginal health services together and try to move in the one direction. Of itself, it is not going to fix things; but it is an essential building block we are going to make progress and not repeat the mistakes of the past. Another essential building block for the long term is the Aboriginal work force. We are not going to have success without male and female Aboriginal health workers on the ground, without them getting adequate training and without there being greater numbers of them. We are not going to have success without research. Research has to underpin any endeavour in health, and particularly in Aboriginal health. We have a very exciting venture happening in Darwin with the Menzies school of medical research. We have $50 miIlion$14 million direct from the Commonwealth and $35 million matched mainly by Commonwealth and state agencies-to spend to look at just the health needs of Aboriginal people. This is a cooperative research centre of the Department of Science and Technology that is looking at Aboriginal well-being. We have 15 coordinated care trials. The first of them are due to start in four weeks time. Three of those 15 are going to be in Aboriginal communities-the Tiwi Islands, the south west of Western Australia, including Roebourne and Bunberry and one in Wilcannia in western New South Wales. Looking at specific strategies, we have an Aboriginal sexual health strategy after a year of tough and difficult negotiation and consultation with Aboriginal people. We have a mental health action plan that, again, does not promise the world but does promise incremental improvements and has taken Aboriginal people on board to be part of it. We have new services starting up-18 that we have been able to announce in the last six months; 17 we are still trying to negotiate the location of with states and territories and Aboriginal people on the basis of need. In places like Balgo, in Western Australia, up to a thousand people have no access to health services whatsoever. On the broader issues, Aboriginal people are now getting their fair share in mainstream programs as well-diabetes, public health, HIV and AIDS. Not all things of course happen because of if government. Some things are happening in spite of government. In the Pitjantjatjara lands, in the north-west of South Australia, there has been the most extraordinary improvements in health in the last four years by Nganampa health services, run out of Alice Springs, where they have been doing the hard slog on the ground and making improvements as good as anywhere in the world, recognising that the improvements come from basic public health strategy. In three shires in the Kimberleys over the last 10 years--only three shires-SID rates amongst men have dropped by two-thirds. The only thing those three shires have in common is that they are the only three shires in the Kimberleys to have an Aboriginal medical service. Mr Dodson is obviously frustrated. I can understand his frustration. Aboriginal people get frustrated when they see $400 million spent by the Commonwealth and states on a royal commission into Aboriginal deaths in custody and Aboriginal death rates go up. Aboriginal people are frustrated when there is a national Aboriginal health strategy that spends $500 million and they can find only traces of it in some places. Australians are generous, and that generosity does extend to improving Aboriginal wellheing. But their generosity will be severely tested if only one side of the argument is put. Their generosity will be severely tested if the view is put around and believed that only bad things are happening, because in many places in the country there are some wonderful, exciting things happening. If the view that everything we do is hopeless does become current, then I am sure the Australian public's generosity will be severely tested. Foreign Debt

Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Minister, have you seen reports in today's newspapers that the Bureau of Meteorology has predicted that the dry El Nino weather pattern will strengthen? What action is the government taking to meet the ongoing welfare needs of farm families in drought affected areas of Australia, including those in south east Queensland?

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for his question. I begin by saying that the government-and I am sure those opposite would share this opinion-is very deeply concerned by the Bureau of Meteorology's confirmation yesterday that large areas of Australia appeared to be heading, again, into drought. The re-emergence of the EI Nino pattern and the continuing negative trend in the southern oscillation index suggest, unfortunately, that the prospect of good rains over winter and spring is increasingly remote. I have to say that the possibility of many farmers not seeing useful rainfall until next autumn is a terrible blow, particularly for those farmers in eastern Australia who are still struggling to recover from what they have been through in recent years-the worse drought on record. I know all of us sincerely hope that it unfolds differently. Nonetheless, of course the government has to be prepared. I point to the fact that, since we came to office last year we have provided some $170 million in additional funding for drought relief. Very importantly, in October last year we extended that drought recovery period from six months to 12 months, in recognition of the ongoing hardship being experienced by farm families. A six-month recovery period was simply insufficient. As a result of that, all eligible farmers in areas where Drought Exceptional Circumstances declarations have been revoked can receive a drought relief payment, which is an income support payment for 12 months. But tragically, even under these circumstances, there are farm families experiencing continuing hardship because of the unbelievable toll taken by drought and the impact of extremely low commodity prices, particularly in the Drought livestock sector. Many families in areas where the 12-month recovery period was due to end next week faced an impossibly bleak immediate future. This included large parts of northern and south-eastern Queensland from where the member comes, north-eastern New South Wales, New England, parts of Tasmania, Victoria and the Eyre Peninsula of South Australia. The government therefore announced earlier today that the drought relief payment would be extended for a further three months in these areas. This will ensure that these hardpressed families continue to be able to put food on the table. The government has granted this extension because it has not yet finalised detailed consultation with stakeholders, including the states and farm leaders, over the integrated rural policy package which is shortly to be announced. It has to be said that this approach can be contrasted very favourably indeed with what farmers saw under the previous administration. text: I thank the honourable member for Menzies for his question. Speaker: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Prime Minister. Isn't it the case that today's economic data, showing growth running at a pathetic 2.4 per cent, is little more than half the level needed to even begin making inroads into unemployment? Doesn't it mean the unemployment outlook is bleak under your government? When will you start to show leadership by creating jobs and getting the unemployment rate down, includand ing the youth unemployment rate that has grown by two per cent in your first 12 months of government?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Both the Treasurer and I have had something to say objectively and, I think, very accurately about the message that comes out of the national accounts. It is clear, if you analyse the national accounts and you make allowances-as the Treasurer quite rightly did in his answer-for the impact of the change in the area of stocks and put that to one side, you can see some very, very positive signs. You can see that net exports made a very - trong contribution. The figures do confirm that consumer demand is picking up, and there is plenty of evidence around-including the most recent approvals figures-showing that the housing sector is beginning to experience quite a firm recovery. There is certainly some very bright news so far as the resource sector is concerned. It is true, as the honourable gentleman knows, that unemployment in this country remains too high. It is also true that high unemployment did not arrive on 2 March 1996. It is true, as the honourable gentleman knows, that high unemployment has been a feature of the Australian economic and political landscape for some time. In fact it reached more than 11 per cent when the honourable gentleman ran the ACTU and Kim Beazley was the employment minister. I do not think anybody who thinks about the unemployment problem should gainsay those undeniable facts. You need higher levels of economic growth in this country-nobody denies that-over a sustained period of time. You also need structural changes to the labour market, which have been begun by this government, the quality and breadth of which are now starting to filter through the business community. Some of the early critics of the Workplace Relations Act, some of those people who said that it did not go far enough, are now beginning to acknowledge the contribution that it will make to freeing the Australian labour market. Only on Monday I had a lengthy meeting with a very representative group of Australian businessmen and women, and the point was made at that gathering that many of the benefits of that act, after a period of five or six months of operation, are now becoming apparent. I might remind the House, remind the Australian people, remind the workers of Australia and remind the employers of Australia that the Australian Labor Party did everything it could to stop that act coming into force. The Australian Labor Party did everything it could to frustrate the coming into force of that legislation-as the Labor Party has done everything it can to frustrate the modifications that have already been made to the unfair dismissal laws and the further modifications that will be made in accordance with the announcement that I made at the time of the small business statement. Unemployment remains a significant economic and political challenge. In the 14 months that I have been Prime Minister, I have never gainsaid that fact. Until the goal that all of us have of a significant reduction in unemployment is reached, it will continue to have that high priority and major preoccupation with my government. In order to reduce unemployment in a sustained way over a long period of time you need higher growth, you need an infinitely more flexibility labour market and you also need taxation reform. One of the things that will help reduce unemployment in this country is the bringing about of taxation reform. That, of course, almost ineluctably brings me again to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition was asked a question when he arrived this morning. That is a fascinating answer because not only has he used some rather crass examples but he completely demonstrates his utter ignorance of how the tax system works. Of course people who are into tax evasion do not sit around filling out their tax forms, whether they are VAT forms, GST forms, income tax forms or sales tax forms. The point I would simply make is that all of the people engaged in the three professional categories to which you referred in your answer, Deputy Leader of the Opposition, do not sit around filling out forms. Living Wage Case Decision

Speaker: Ms JEANES
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. The recent decision of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in the living wage case ensured real wage increases for low-income earners. What is the government's position on the maintenance of the award system as a safety net for low-income earners in my electorate of Kingston? How does it contrast with other points of view?

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Kingston for her question. It is very important to look at the way in which we are going to use our industrial relations system to improve the living standards of people in her electorate of Kingston and generally throughout the country. One of the good things about the recent living wage case decision of the Industrial Relations Commission was that it was a fair deal for low-income people. Because it was economically responsible it also paved the way for the interest rates cuts which were forms? later announced by the Reserve Bank. The point about having awards as merely a safety net is that this provides you with a system that looks after the people who need to be looked after. It also opens up the system for those beyond the safety net to do productivity based deals which give them the chance of earning more. We are not reinventing the wheel here. This used to be the policy so espoused by the opposition when they were in government, which is a policy they are now officially opposed to. You have the gang of four out there opposing the very reforms to the system which they themselves said would be good for low-income earners as well as which would give us a low inflation environment, thereby paving the way for better deals for people throughout the system, including particularly low-income people. You do not get a $292 benefit in terms of lower and reduced interest rates just as a result of circumstance: it is as a result of good policy in both the fiscal area and in the wages area, giving better outcomes. We have seen-when you make these comparisons with other points of view-the ACTU put their living wage claim into the AIRC. Who are they supported by? The ALP. We saw the TWU run a case which was directly opposed to a system that would give benefits to low-income people. Who supported the TWU? None other than the ALP. We have seen the ALP jettison enterprise bargaining, which they once said was good for lowincome people but which now, of course, is not populist. We have seen them abandon non-union certified agreements, which they themselves, in theory at least, once supported and which they now oppose. Essentially, what you have in this debate and with this point of view is the gang of four-the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the two ex-ACTU presidents-running the ACTU line. We know this is starting to generate a few problems within their own ranks. We have seen announced in the press today this sinister conspiracy by others who are mounting some economically literate argument against the gang of four position. There is a bit of unhappiness in the mid-party, cadre levels about economic policy and, in particular, industrial relations. What we now see is a challenge to the centralised wage system which, if you go back to the 1970s and the 1980s, was in fact the position of the ALP. The challenge, of course, is coming from none other than the member for Melbourne, backed up by the member for Werriwa. This is what the member for Melbourne had to say about wages policy. He said the party should: . . . accept that the detenuination of tenus and conditions in the higher-earning sector of the workforce will be much more dominated by the market than previously. The award system can no longer be a comprehensive prescription of tenus and conditions of employment for everyone ... Wages policy should focus primarily on using the award system to increase the real earnings of income workers. So there you have it. You have the economically literate running the proposition that the award should be the safety net, and you have the gang of four-including the two ACTU ex-presidents-running the same old Labor line, which is that you have to have a centralised wage-fixing system, you do not have real and genuine enterprise bargaining, you should have compulsory unionism and you should give as much power to the trade union bosses as they demand of you. In Labour terms, this is a return to a sort purist ideology. This is where they once were. This is the trip down nostalgia lane which the member for Melbourne referred to. But, as Gough Whitlam once said-and perhaps these immortal words were written by the member for Werriwa in his past life-at a time of yet another split in the party: 'Certainly, the impotent are pure.' Tax Pack

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: That's right. Let us have a look at the fourteenth year, since you raise it. A couple of examples will suffice. Labor's forward estimates for the 1997-98 year showed $171 million on environmental programs. It was on the way down, but there was $171 million. This year, in that same year, we will spend $255 million, an increase of $84 million-a 50 per cent increase over what they claimed they were going to spend. But it gets better. Labor's forward estimates for the following year, 1998-99, were $147 million. That year, we will spend $267 million, an increase of 80 per cent. So let us knock firmly on the head any suggestion that somehow we are not really going to spend as much as they are. We are spending a lot more, despite the problems that we faced as a government in repairing your black hole and the undoubted pressures that put on our outlays. I will tell you something else. Not only is our environment program a massive increase on your proposals; it is very important to note that it is a fully-funded program. Your entire budget strategy was to spend more money on Australia's Bankcard. You wanted to impose the debt on future generations. Now the next point is that the Commonwealth's Natural Heritage Trust funding will be complemented-this is very important-by resources provided by state governments and community groups and farmers in partnership as part of a concerted effort. So, overall, the level of resources devoted to this task will be enormous. Mr Crean-Page two.

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Yes. That's right. We haven't finished. Most of the trust funds are available to the wider community as grants through programs such as the national landcare program, the national vegetation and national rivercare initiatives and Murray-Darling 2001. Coming to the other issue raised by the honourable member, I make this point. The process is open, transparent and accountable. Applications from community groups and others will be assessed and prioritised by community-dominated regional and state assessment panels. They will have access to specialist technical advice and projects will be assessed against national, state and regional priorities. There is no political involvement whatsoever. It is a process of integrity. It builds on structures that have been in place for a long time, structures that you largely put in place with bipartisan support from us. It is worth noting that over 5,000 applications are now in. They will be properly and rigorously processed. People at the grassroots levelwhere the action is needed-are clearly getting on with the job. Employment Growth

Speaker: Mr WILLIS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. The question concerns the growth in employment of only 92,000 in the first 14 months of this government and the budget forecast for employment growth of 2111 per cent in each of the next two years. Is the Prime Minister aware that, if these budget forecasts for employment growth are delivered, his government will have achieved 443,000 additional jobs at the end of three years compared with 733,000 additional jobs in Labor's last term of office? How does he equate this projected shortfall of 290,000 jobs with his pre-election promise to boost jobs growth?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: That question might well have been directed to my colleague the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, who I thought spent the best part of the first 12 months that we were in government effectively debunking the myth of massive job generation during the years of the Labor Party. Let me take the opportunity, which the member for Gellibrand's question affords me, of saying a few things about the future and saying a few things about measures that have been announced, will come on stream and into effect over coming months, and will, in the assessment of the government, have a beneficial impact upon jobs, particularly in rural and regional Australia. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy drew attention in an earlier answer to a new rural policy statement, which will be made in the second half of this year, which will involve, over a number of years, an investment of some $200 million. That will have a very beneficial impact on job generation in country Australia. There will be a regional forest agreement in Tasmania, to be signed soon, which will give greater certainty for investment in that state and greater certainty for the environment in that state. The minister for primary industries has already referred to the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia. I wonder, in the context of the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia, whether the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats realise that, in voting against it, you were voting against the generation of Australian jobs. I wonder whether you realise that, in voting against that measure, you were voting against the creation of potentially hundreds, if not thousands, of jobs in rural and regional Australia. I wonder whether every time you join the divisions against that measure, both here and in the Senate, you realise how hostile your behaviour appeared then and will continue to appear to people who live in rural and regional Australia. Further down the track there will be the $1 billion Federation Fund for projects of national significance. I know it is not really the custom of those who sit opposite to think about the future. I know it is not really the custom of those who sit opposite to focus on some of the positives. As I said in answer to a question from the member for Batman, I do not pretend for a moment that unemployment does not remain a very significant social and economic challenge. The reality is that we have established the fundamentals. We have tackled the budget problem. We have kept inflation low. We have presided over significant falls in interest rates. The benefits of those falls in interest rates are traditionally delayed by something like a year or 18 months. As they begin to flow through, as the other measures that we have put in place begin to flow through, as the job-generating consequences and flowthrough effects of some of the proposals that I have canvassed in this answer begin to flow through, and putting all of those together, I believe that they will make a much brighter and more positive contribution to the jobs outlook in Australia. I know those who sit opposite are gloomy at the prospect that any measure announced might have a beneficial effect on the labour market of Australia. I simply remind you that 11.1 per cent under your leader was the postrecession high of unemployment. Just remember that it was not until Kim Beazley became employment minister that unemployment in Australia went over 11 per cent. That is a shameful record and one about which you will constantly be reminded. Christmas Island

Speaker: Mr DONDAS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government. Can the minister advise the House as to what the current economic position is in respect of Christmas Island? What recent initiatives has the government taken to improve the economy in this area of my electorate?

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for the Northern Territory for his question. His question related to the Indian Ocean island teqitories, which are made up of Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Island. The decision in the budget was to increase the allocation for Christmas and Cocos islands by $3 million, in addition to the amount of about $30 million already paid to those islands to improve health services, education services, local government and other such services. Those members who have some knowledge about Christmas Island will know that it has a phosphate mine on it. We are just in the process of finalising the extension of a lease for the continuation of the mine, which is a centrepiece of the economics of Christmas Island for a further 25 years. In so doing, we have required of the mine a program for dust suppression. Those who have visited Christmas Island will know that that has been a major problem. The mine has entered into agreements to do that. That will underpin, in a most positive way, the future economics of Christmas Island. Also, the considerable difficulties with the Christmas Island resort have now been resolved, and that resort reopened at the weekend. Westpac Bank, for example, have continued with their banking services, to the delight of all on Christmas Island. On Cocos Island, in the last 12 months we have proceeded with a land release program, and those properties have been sold. Also, there has been an upgrading of planning on both islands to foster their economic development. What is important in both of those islands is the continuation of a strategy to improve economic well-being so that the services and opportunities put Islanders in a position where they can enjoy services at a comparable level to the rest of Australians. The Indian Ocean island territories are a remote part of Australia and this government is proud that, in the last 12 months since the election, we have been able to further this strategy. I do thank the member for the Northern Territory, who has, since he assumed the position, taken a keen interest in the welfare of those on Cocos and Christmas islands. His representations have been listened to and we have been able to deliver the goods to those islands. Diesel Fuel Rebate

Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Adelaide for her question. I draw the House's attention to her long interest in commemorating the sacrifices of service nurses and servicewomen and also her support for the recently unveiled memorial in South Australia to ex-service women. I have seen the film review referred to by the member for Adelaide. There have also been other reviews which have questioned the film's portrayal of the brutality and suffering endured by those who experienced life in a Japanese prisoner of war camp. These reviews have caused veterans, particularly former prisoners of war, a great deal of hurt. For them, the memories are still very vivid and very painful but, for some ill-informed film reviewers, they do not want us to forget or to cleanse those stories. The Bruce Beresford written and directed film Paradise Road is being released throughout Australia this week. It tells the story of a group of Australian and allied nurses, civilians and children imprisoned in a Japanese prisoner of war camp in Sumatra during W orId War II. Veterans and former service nurses who have seen the film, in fact some who were prisoners of war in the camp on which the film is based, say it is an accurate record of what happened. That should be good enough for the film critics. It is the opinion of those who were there that is important. We must never underestimate the importance of telling history as it really was. Current and future generations of Australians need to understand history.

Speaker: Mr CAUSLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Are state governments cooperating with the federal government in the program?

Speaker: Mr SHARP
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Page for his question. He has taken a deep interest in roads in his electorate, as have a number of members on the government side in their electorates. As the member for Page correctly points out, these roads are vital to regional Australia because they are the artery to the economy of Australia. This government, prior to the last election, had a policy to establish a new category for Commonwealth road funding called 'roads of national importance'. Chief amongst them was the establishment of a fund to upgrade the Pacific Highway. In partnership with both the New South Wales and Queensland governments, this coalition government has fulfilled its election promise of allocating some $3.1 billion towards upgrading the Pacific Highway over the next 10 years to bring it up to a standard it should have been a long time ago. Indeed, this is something that the previous Labor government could have done but failed to do. Like so many other promises they are now making, they say they would have done it had they had a 14th or 15thÂ·year of office. The member for Page is also concerned about other roads of national importance and, in particular, one in his electorate called Summerland Way. This government, in order to fulfil its commitments made prior to the last election, has allocated funds to upgrade the Summerland Way, an important link from the honourable member's electorate to Brisbane and other parts of Queensland. We have allocated funds to upgrade that road over the next four years. Unfortunately, there have been some difficulties in getting the New South Wales government to cooperate in this program-as usual, Labor not putting the resources where they are most needed to upgrade these important roads. However, last Friday officials from my department and officials from the Roads and Traffic Authority in New South Wales met. I now call on the New South Wales government to come good with their promise of some $50 million towards the upgrade of the Summerland Way. I call upon them to fulfil their commitment and come up with the other funds that the Commonwealth is now prepared to make available to see the Summerland Way improve, according to the wishes of not only the honourable member for Page but indeed many people throughout northern New South Wales and southern Queensland, who see the vital importance of upgrading this road for the local economies in that regional part of Australia. Fair Trading

Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Small Business and Customs. I refer the minister to a case study within the fair trading inquiry report, Finding a balance. Despite offering to pay more rent, they were told to change to a far worse location or face eviction by the centre management. They were evicted in May 1996. If he will recall, when I set up the inquiry in May of last year I said that generally we think there are three important areas that should be looked at: tenancy, franchising and fuel retailing. Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The workers I am worried about are the workers who have been denied jobs because of your stupid laws. They are the workers I am worried about. I am worried about the thousands of young men and women around Australia who were denied jobs when you were in government. They were denied jobs because small employers were frightened to take them on. No amount of phoney, grubby scare campaigning by the Labor Party can alter the fact that the laws you brought in discriminated against the young unemployed. The laws you brought in intimidated small business people out of taking on young people. The law that we have proposed, which you intend to knock off in the Senate, would have created hundreds, potentially thousands, more jobs. What is your answer to that? Your answer is to vote against it. What is your answer to our every attempt to create jobs for young people via the Natural Heritage Trust, via better unfair dismissal law and via many other changes? Your answer is to vote against it. The reason you vote against it is that Jennie George told you to do so. The very day that the legislation was brought out, that was made painfully apparent in the doorstops that you and Senator Cook conducted. She came right over the top and said, 'You've got to vote against it.' Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper. NA Members and Guests Dining Room: Dried Apricots

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER

text: I thank the member for Canberra for his multifaceted question. I will take most of it on notice. Speaker: Mrs SULLIVAN
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, my question relates to the response you gave to this morning's request by the right honourable member for New England that you 'advise when and in what circumstances we take two successive divisions without the application of the new procedures of counting'; namely, your reply that, 'The honourable member for Dobell actually began to debate the issue and that automatically ruled out a successive division. Notwithstanding the fact that the bells were allowed to ring for one minute, it does require a separate count.' Could you confirm that standing order 200 requires that the doors be closed and locked for the counting of a division after the lapse of four minutes, and the ringing of the bells for one minute is provided for in sessional order 203A which relates only to successive divisions? Mr Leo MCLeay-Is she giving you an advisory position?

Speaker: Mrs SULLIVAN
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: Wait a minute. I have waited long enough. Now you can just wait a minute. Since the time for the ringing of the bells for the different types of divisions is mandated by the sessional and standing orders, could you please advise the House why the bells for the division I have referred to were rung for one minute and not four minutes, if it was not a 'successive' division? In considering your response to this question, would you please inform the House whether pages 4400 to 4404 of the Hansard for 2 June 1997 and pages 8449 to 8456 of the Hansard for 12 December 1996 might indicate that the conduct of any of the divisions detailed there were out of order? What is the validity of a division which has not been conducted in accordance with the requirements of the House's sessional and standing orders? What are the consequences or implications for matters deemed to have been passed by this House if the conduct of any of the relevant divisions did not conform with sessional and standing orders?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: I thank the honourable member for Moncrieff for her totally unexpected question. Members would realise that the sessional divisions are still in a state of flux. I think that the honourable member for Prospect called the first one within the last 48 hours or so. After the division this morning, we reviewed the circumstances and, while I will not address all of the questions that you have raised-I will take the balance of those on notice-I do have a comment that I would like to make, and I do thank you for your question. The trial arrangement for the abbrevia,,- 1 taking of a successive division is set out i sessional orders 203A and 203B and was used for the first time this week. Sessional order 203A provides that, where successive divisions are taken and there is no intervening debate after the first division, the bells for the ensuing division shall be rung for one minute only. Sessional order 203B makes provision for an abbreviated taking of the count for a successive division in circumstances where members are voting in the same way as they did in the preceding division. An example of such circumstances would be where a government motion is closured followed immediately by a vote on the motion itself with the government members voting the same way. The point at issue relates to the interpretation of the words in sessional order 203A 'where there is no intervening debate'. Taken literally, this means that any debate such as the seconding of a motion or the moving of the closure amounts to intervening debate, and the shortened method of conducting the division does not apply. This is the way in which I applied the sessional orders this morning. I recognise that there may thought to be some inconsistency between my application of the new sessional order in respect of the actual counting and the practice of the chair adopted under the old standing order 200A of frequently, but not always, ordering the bells to be rung for one minute only for a following division. This is a practice which the House has developed over some years. Because of the newness of the counting methods provided for in sessional order 203B, the House has not yet had an opportunity to develop a practice in relation to the new counting arrangements. I assume from the comments that have been made that it is the wish of members that the new abbreviated counting method be used where there is no debate beyond formal words such as 'I second the motion'. In these circumstances, I will be happy to apply the abbreviated arrangements.
